== Awards ==
===Drama Desk Awards=== * 1993: Revival of a Play – ''[[Anna Christie]]'' * 1994: Musical Revival – ''[[She Loves Me]]'' * 1998: Revival of a Musical – ''[[Cabaret (musical)|Cabaret]]'' * 1998: Revival of a Play – ''[[A View From the Bridge]]'' * 2003: Revival of a Musical – ''[[Nine (musical)|Nine]]'' * 2004: Revival of a Musical – ''[[Assassins]]'' * 2005: Revival of a Play – ''[[Twelve Angry Men (play)|Twelve Angry Men]]'' * 2008: Unique Theatrical Experience – ''[[The 39 Steps (play)|The 39 Steps]]'' * 2011: Revival of a Musical – ''[[Anything Goes]]''
=== Laurence Olivier Awards === * 1995; Best Musical Revival – ''[[She Loves Me]]''
===Lucille Lortel Awards=== Roundabout productions have received 9 [[Lucille Lortel Awards]]. Derek McLane and Catherine Zuber won Outstanding Set and Costume Design Awards for 2004's ''Intimate Apparel''. Reg Rogers won an Outstanding Actor award for 2002's ''The Dazzle''. Kenneth Posner won an Outstanding Lighting Design Award for 2000's ''Give Me Your Answer, Do!'' Robert Brill with Scott Pask, Jess Goldstein, and Kevin Adams won Awards for Outstanding Set, Costume, and Lighting Design for 1999's ''The Mineola Twins''. 1998's ''All My Sons'' won an award for Outstanding Revival. 1996's ''Molly Sweeney'' won an award for Outstanding Play of the Season.
===Theatre World Awards=== 29 Performers in Roundabout productions have won [[Theatre World Award]]s, which honors achievement in "breakout" performances. Winners are Christopher Goutman in 1979's ''The Promise'', Boyd Gaines in 1981's ''A Month in the Country'', Lisa Banes in 1981's ''Look Back in Anger'', Anthony Heald in 1982's ''Misalliance'', Kate Burton in 1983's ''Winners'', Mark Capri in 1985's ''On Approval'', Lindsay Crouse in 1992's ''[[The Homecoming]]'', Natasha Richardson and Liam Neeson in 1993's ''Anna Christie'', Calista Flockhart and Kevin Kilner in 1995's ''[[The Glass Menagerie]]'', Helen Mirren in 1995's ''A Month in the Country'', Alfred Molina in 1996's ''Molly Sweeney'', Helen Carey in 1997's ''London Assurance'', Alan Cumming in 1998's ''[[Cabaret (musical)|Cabaret]]'', Henry Czerny in 2000's ''Arms and the Man'', Juliette Binoche in 2001's Betrayal, David Warner in 2002's ''Major Barbara'', Victoria Hamilton in 2003's ''A Day in the Death of Joe Egg'', Antonio Banderas and Mary Stuart Masterson for 2003's ''Nine'', Alexander Gemignani in 2004's ''Assassins'', Carla Gugino in 2005's ''After the Fall'', Mamie Gummer in 2006's ''Mr. Marmalade'', Nellie McKay in 2006's ''The Threepenny Opera'', Harry Connick Jr. in 2006's ''The Pajama Game'', Ben Daniels in 2008's ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses'', and Jenna Russell in 2008's ''Sunday in the Park with George''.
===Tony Awards=== * 1993: Revival – ''[[Anna Christie]]'' * 1998: Revival of a Musical – ''[[Cabaret (musical)|Cabaret]]'' * 1998: Revival of a Play – ''[[A View From the Bridge]]'' * 1999: New Play – ''[[Side Man]]'' * 2003: Revival of a Musical – ''[[Nine (musical)|Nine]]'' * 2004: Revival of a Musical – ''[[Assassins]]'' * 2005: Revival of a Play – ''[[Glengarry Glen Ross]]'' * 2006: Revival of a Musical – ''[[The Pajama Game]]'' * 2011: Revival of a Musical – ''[[Anything Goes]]''
===Village Voice Obie Awards=== They have won 7 Village Voice [[Obie Awards]]. 2004's ''Intimate Apparel'', 2003's ''All Over'', 2002's ''The Dazzle'', 1999's ''The Mineola Twins'', and 1981's ''The Chalk Garden'' won Performance Awards for Viola Davis, Rosemary Harris, Peter Frechette and Reg Rogers, Swoosie Kurtz, and Irene Worth respectively. Emily Mann also won a Direction Obie Award for 2003's ''All Over''.
===Other awards=== Roundabout has received 41 [[Outer Critics Circle Awards]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | image = The Oracle (i).gif | imagesize = | caption = Foster in ''The Matrix Reloaded'' as The Oracle | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1933|11|15|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Chicago, Illinois]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2001|9|29|1933|11|15|mf=y}} | death_place = [[New York City]] | other_names = | website = | academyawards = | emmyawards = | occupation = Actress | spouse = [[Clarence Williams III]] }}
'''Gloria Foster''' (November 15, 1933 - September 29, 2001)<ref name=SSDI>{{cite web|title=Gloria Foster|url=http://www.americanancestors.org/PageDetail.aspx?recordId=101145878|work=Social Security Death Index|publisher=New England Historic Genealogical Society|accessdate=17 April 2011}}</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[actress]], most known for her stage performances portraying an array of Black characters, including her acclaimed roles in plays ''In White America'' and ''[[Having Our Say]],''<ref name=ny>[http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B03E1D7163CF936A35753C1A9679C8B63 Gloria Foster, Stage Actress, Is Dead at 64] ''[[New York Times]], October 5, 2001.</ref> winning three [[Obie Awards]] during her career.
In films, she was perhaps best known as [[Oracle (Matrix character)|The Oracle]] in ''[[The Matrix]]'' (1999) and ''[[The Matrix Reloaded]]'' (2003), the latter film being her last.<ref>[http://www.blackfilm.com/20030509/features/aamatrix.shtml Gloria Foster as The Oracle - Profile] ''blackfilm.com''.</ref>
==Early life== Gloria Foster was born on November 15, 1933 in [[Chicago, Illinois]]. But as a young child she was put into custody of her mother's grandparents. Gloria Foster never knew who her father was and she moved to [[Janesville, Wisconsin]] after her mother was hospitalized for a mental illness.<ref name="playbill.com">[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/62727-Actress-Gloria-Foster-Is-Remembered-at-Manhattan-Memorial Actress Gloria Foster article after her death] ''[[Playbill]]''.</ref> Her grandmother, Eleanor Sudds, and her grandfather, Clyde Sudds, raised Gloria Foster on a farm. As Gloria continued her education she returned to her hometown of Chicago and attended the [[University of Illinois]], where she participated in plays, but did not focus on it. She took many different classes, including forensics, which she enjoyed a lot.<ref name="Shafer, Yvonne 2000">Shafer, Yvonne. "Gloria Foster." Performing O'Neil: Conversations with Actors and Directors. New York: St. Martin's , 2000. 215-231. Print] "[[Performing O'Neil]]".</ref> Gloria Foster was not sure what occupation to pursue, until her godmother introduced her to the [[Goodman Theatre]] in [[Chicago]].<ref name="Shafer, Yvonne 2000"/> After she auditioned and was accepted, she knew that this was going to be her passion in life, the theater. She was one of the few African Americans at the Goodman School of Drama, but focused on her study of acting. During her studying at the Goodman School she also, "learned professional acting skills in the Court Theater at the University of Chicago".<ref name="on actress Gloria Foster">[http://www.kosmix.com/topic/gloria_foster-Gloria-Foster-biography on actress Gloria Foster] ''[[Kosmix]]''.</ref> One of her most influential instructors was Bella Itkin, who cast Gloria in many classical roles.<ref name="playbill.com"/> Her next step in life was to move to New York to pursue a career on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]].
==Acting career== Gloria Foster began her career on Broadway as she moved to New York in 1963.<ref name="on actress Gloria Foster"/> Her first role was Ruth in the show of ''[[A Raisin in the Sun]]''. She started an acting career as her agent, Ernestine McClendon, sent her on an audition for ''[[In White America]]''.<ref name="playbill.com"/> The play was about the history of blacks in the United States and the oppression they had to face. Gloria Foster, "play[s] a 13-year-old Arkansas girl who tries to enter her Little Rock school".<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/2001/10/05/theater/gloria-foster-stage-actress-is-dead-at-67.html] ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref> This was her first distinction and had to play 27 different characters. This led to her winning an [[Obie Award]] or Off-Broadway Theater Award, which is an, "annual award bested by The Village Voice newspaper to theater artists and groups in New York City". She also received a two-page article in ''[[Life (magazine)|Life Magazine]]'', explaining about the wonderful performance and critics said she was up and coming and people should look out for the next pieces she performs in.<ref>[http://www.tributemovies.com/people/Gloria+Foster/10800/] [[Tribute (magazine)|Tribute Movies]].</ref> She performed many other plays in New York and on Broadway and the public started to notice her, as she became a bigger star. Not only did the public start to notice her, but also critics began analyzing her performances. They wrote that she performed her roles as a, "majestic, full-voiced, statuesque and stunning actress".<ref name="playbill.com"/> The passion she had for acting was reflected in her performances and an unusual thing happened for her, "an African-American actress around whom producers and directors built production".<ref name="playbill.com"/> Instead of Gloria Foster having to audition for roles, people started to make parts for her to be in. It was her spirit, excitement, and stamina for acting that gave her success in such a hard business. She was a breakthrough artist who, "played roles previously inaccessible to Blacks".<ref>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1355/is_19_100/ai_79477125/Actress-Gloria-Foster-Succumbs-At-Age-64] ''[[BNET]]''.</ref>
Gloria Foster, instead of searching for fame by trying to be in many different productions, searched for roles in which she would be able to perform at the best of her ability. She once said, "Young people today, I think, are thinking in terms of stepping stones…I don't know that I ever thought that way. It sounds ridiculous, but I was always thinking in terms of a more difficult role".<ref name="playbill.com"/> She won fame by performing her roles magnificently, not by performing the maximum number of roles that she could. She read many scripts, but only chose the ones that spoke truly to her. By the end of her acting career, she was rewarded with three Obie awards, for ''In White America'' (1963) and ''A Raisin In the Sun'', and was in the Broadway production of ''[[Having Our Say]]'' (1995).<ref>[McCann, Bob. "Foster, Gloria." Encyclopedia of African American Actresses in Film and Television. North Carolina: McFarland & Company, 2010. 121-22. Print.] ''[[Encyclopedia of African American Actresses in Film and Television]]''.</ref>
In the early 1970s, Foster was admitted to a special graduate program in education at [[University of Massachusetts Amherst|UMass]].<ref>[http://umassmag.com/Archives/1996/fall_96/biteapple.html#anchor732084 Gloria Foster Biography] [[University of Massachusetts Amherst|UMass]].</ref>
==Personal life== Gloria Foster was married to the actor, [[Clarence Williams III]] in 1967. They met on the television show ''[[The Mod Squad]]'' that ran from the late 1960s to the early 1970s. The show was a police drama that featured three young hip crime fighters. In the show Clarence Williams played the black cop, Linc Hayes. Foster made two guest appearances on the show. The two also were in a movie, ''[[The Cool World (film)|The Cool World]]'', in 1964 together. In 1984 they filed for a divorce, but remained friends.<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0929934/bio-Clarence-Williams-III] ''[[IMDb]]''.</ref> Williams was the one to announce her death in 2001. While Foster did not have many close relatives, it is known that she stayed in contact with her sister-in-law, [[Cicely Tyson]]. Tyson stated that although they did not see each other often, their telephone conversations would often last for hours.<ref name="playbill.com"/> She was a member of [[Delta Sigma Theta]] sorority.
==Highlights== Moving from the New York stage, Gloria Foster started to do roles on the big screen. She was in many theatrical performances and also performed some roles on television.
''[[The Cool World (film)|The Cool World]]'' (1964)- This was Gloria Foster's first appearance on a full-length feature film. She played Mrs. Custis. It was on the set of this film that she starred next to her future husband, Clarence Williams III.<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0056952/-The-Cool-World] [[IMDb]].</ref>
''[[Nothing But a Man]]'' (1964)- Gloria Foster plays a woman named Lee, who lives with the main character's (Duff Anderson) father.<ref>[http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title.jsp?stid=85269-Nothing-But-A-Man] ''[[Turner Classic Movies]]''.</ref>
She was also active in [[television]], appearing in such programs as ''[[I Spy (1965 TV series)|I Spy]]'', two episodes of ''[[Law & Order]]'' and ''[[The Cosby Show]]'' (1987).
Her character in both ''Law and Order'' episodes was based on the widow of [[Malcolm X]], [[Betty Shabazz]]. The first episode was based on Malcolm X's assassination, Malcolm X played by [[Hal Miller (actor)|Hal Miller]], while the second focused on her character's children's acts of revenge against those who they thought were really responsible.
She returned to theater again in 1995, acting alongside [[Mary Alice]] (who was later to replace her in ''[[The Matrix]]'' films following her death), appearing as 103-year-old [[Sarah Louise Delany|Sadie Delany]], in ''Having Our Say'', on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] at the [[Booth Theatre]], for which she received rave reviews.<ref name=ca>[http://www.tribute.ca/people/Gloria+Foster/10800/587 Gloria Foster bio: The Matrix Actor]</ref><ref>[http://www.villagevoice.com/2001-10-09/theater/gloria-foster-1936-2001/ Gloria Foster (1936–2001)] ''Villagevoice.com'', Robert Simonson, October 9, 2001.</ref>
''[[The Matrix]]'' (1999)- Gloria Foster played the Oracle. The Oracle helps Neo find out if he is "the one". Because the movie did so well, this role was very important to Gloria Foster's career.<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0133093/-The-Matirx] [[IMDb]].</ref>
''[[The Matrix Reloaded]]'' (2003)- Gloria Foster continued to act the role of the Oracle, but unfortunately died during the filming and [[Mary Alice]] continued the role in ''[[The Matrix Revolutions]]'' and ''[[Enter the Matrix]]''.
==Death==
Gloria Foster died on September 29, 2001 at age 67. The cause of her death was [[diabetes]]. Though she was no longer married, her ex-husband, [[Clarence Williams III]], was the one to announce her death. A memorial was held at [[Cypress Hills Cemetery]] in Brooklyn on October 15, 2001.<ref name="nytimes.com">[http://www.nytimes.com/2001/10/05/theater/gloria-foster-stage-actress-is-dead-at-64.html] ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref> Many of her close friends and also actors and actresses that had performed with her came to attend the funeral. Judith Rutherford James, a well-known producer and also good friend who worked with Gloria Foster on ''In White America'' and ''Having Our Say'' was a huge part in the memorial service and helped to oversee that it ran smoothly.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> Many of the speeches given at the service, showed and spoke about how Gloria Foster not only played her part, but also embodied the character, both emotionally and also physically. Duberman, the author of ''In White America'', told the audience that, "she embodied it. At the end of the scene each night, there were tears streaming down her face, her body was trembling, but her dignity was intact"… "Foster had to be covered with blankets in order to calm her shaking".<ref name="nytimes.com"/> She is interred in [[Kensico Cemetery]] in [[Valhalla, New York]].
== Filmography == * '''[[Film]]s''' ** ''[[The Matrix Reloaded]]'' (2003) as [[The Oracle (The Matrix)|The Oracle]] ** ''[[The Matrix]]'' (1999) as [[The Oracle (The Matrix)|The Oracle]] ** ''[[City of Hope (film)|City of Hope]]'' (1991) as Jeanette ** ''[[Leonard Part 6]]'' (1987) as Medusa ** ''[[Man and Boy (1972 film)|Man and Boy]]'' (1972) as Ivy Revers ** ''[[The Angel Levine (film)|The Angel Levine]]'' (1970) as Sally ** ''[[The Comedians (novel)|The Comedians]]'' (1967) as Mrs. Philipot ** ''[[Nothing But a Man]]'' (1964) as Lee ** ''[[The Cool World (film)|The Cool World]]'' (1964) as Mrs. Custis * '''[[Television]]''' ** ''[[Percy & Thunder]]'' (1993) as Sugar Brown ** ''[[Law & Order]]'' (1992) as Mrs. Tate ** ''[[Separate But Equal]]'' (1991) as Buster ** ''[[The Cosby Show]]'' (1987) as Dr. Barbara Bracy ** ''[[The Atlanta Child Murders (TV miniseries)|The Atlanta Child Murders]]'' (1985) (miniseries) as Camille Bell ** ''[[The House of Dies Drear|House of Dies Drear]]'' (1984) as Sheila Small ** ''[[The Files on Jill Hatch]]'' (1983) as Mrs. Hatch ** ''[[Top Secret (1978 film)|Top Secret]]'' (1978) as Judith ** ''[[To All My Friends on Shore]]'' (1972) as Serena

{{About|the later playwright of this name|the earlier playwright|John Patrick (dramatist)|other persons of the same name|John Patrick (disambiguation){{!}}John Patrick}} {{refimproveBLP|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox playwright | name = John Patrick Shanley | image = JohnPatrickShanley-2011.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1950|10|3|}} | birth_place = [[The Bronx, New York]], [[United States|USA]] | nationality = United States | alma_mater = [[New York University]] | spouse = Jayne Haynes | occupation = [[Playwright]] and [[Screenwriter]] | period = | genre = | ploys = | debut_works = ''Welcome to the Moon'' (1982)
''[[Women of Manhattan]]'' (1986) | notable_works = | known_for = ''[[Doubt: A Parable]]'' (2004){{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} | collaborator = | influences = | influenced = | awards = [[Academy Award]] (1988), [[Pulitzer Prize for Drama]] (2005), [[Tony Award]] (2005) | academy_awards = 1988 [[Academy Award for Best Screenplay]]: ''[[Moonstruck]]'' }} '''John Patrick Shanley''' (born October 3, 1950) is an American [[playwright]], [[screenwriter]], and [[Film director|director]]. He also contributed articles on the performing arts to ''[[The New York Times]]'' among other publications. ==Life and career== Shanley was born in [[The Bronx]], [[New York City]], to a telephone operator mother and a meat-packer father.http://www.filmreference.com/film/58/John-Patrick-Shanley.html Per his Editorial Review by Amazon, he was thrown out of St. Helene's kindergarten, banned from St. Anthony's hot lunch program and expelled from Cardinal Spellman High School. When asked why he had been treated in this way, he burst into tears and said he had no idea. Then he went into the [[United States Marines]].Alex Witchel, "The Confessions of John Patrick Shanley," ''The New York Times Magazine'', November 7, 2004. He is a graduate of [[New York University]], and is a member of the [[Ensemble Studio Theatre]].http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/s/john_patrick_shanley/index.html?inline=nyt-per For his script for the 1987 film, ''[[Moonstruck]]'', Shanley won the [[Academy Award]] for [[Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay|Best Original Screenplay]] and the [[Writers Guild of America|Writers Guild of America Award for Best Screenplay Written Directly for the Screen]]. In 1990, Shanley directed his script of ''[[Joe Versus the Volcano]].'' Shanley also wrote two songs for the movie: "Marooned Without You" and "The Cowboy Song." In 2002 Shanley was inducted into the [[The Bronx|Bronx Walk of Fame]].[http://www.ilovethebronx.com/walkofame?field_walk_of_fame_years_value%5Bvalue%5D%5Byear%5D=2004 Bronx Walk of Fame Inductees, 2004] In 2005, Shanley's play ''[[Doubt: A Parable]]'' was awarded the [[Pulitzer Prize for Drama]] and the [[Drama Desk Award]] and [[Tony Award]] for Best Play. ''Doubt: A Parable'', is featured in The Fourth Wall, a book of photographs by [[Amy Arbus]] in which Shanley also wrote the foreword. In 2008, Shanley directed a film version of ''[[Doubt (2008 film)|Doubt]]'' starring [[Meryl Streep]], [[Philip Seymour Hoffman]], [[Amy Adams]] and [[Viola Davis]].[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0918927/ IMDB, ''Doubt''] Today, Shanley resides in New York. In 2012, Shanley wrote the libretto for an opera version of "[[Doubt: A Parable]]" which is set to premiere at the [[Minnesota Opera]] in January, 2013. He told how the opera version came about, even though he knew little about opera, in [http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424127887323482504578229531515182640.html] a Jan. 17. 2013 article in the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]''. In the same spirit, the playwright offered this February 11, 2013, ''[[New York Times]]'' [[op-ed]] : "[http://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/12/opinion/farewell-to-an-uninspiring-pope.html Farewell to an Uninspiring Pope]". ==Work== {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=50%}} ===Stage=== *''Welcome to the Moon'' (1982) *''Danny and the Deep Blue Sea'' (1983) *''[[Savage in Limbo]]'' (1984) *''The Dreamer Examines His Pillow'' (1985) *''[[Italian American Reconciliation]]'' (1986) *''[[Women of Manhattan]]'' (1986) *''All For Charity'' (1987) *''The Big Funk'' (1990) *''Beggars in the House of Plenty'' (1991) *''What Is This Everything?'' (1992) *''Kissing Christine'' (1995) *''Missing Marisa'' (1995) *''Four Dogs and a Bone'' (1993) *''The Wild Goose'' (1995) *''[[Psychopathia Sexualis (play)|Psychopathia Sexualis]]'' (1998) *''Where's My Money?'' (2001) *''[[Cellini (play)|Cellini]]'' (2001) *''[[Dirty Story]]'' (2003) *''[[Doubt: A Parable]]'' (2004) *''Sailor's Song'' (2004) *''[[Defiance (play)|Defiance]]'' (2005) *''Romantic Poetry'' (2007) - cowritten with [[Henry Krieger]] *''Pirate'' (2010) *''Storefront Church'' (2012) {{col-break}} ===Filmography=== *''[[Moonstruck]]'' (1987) ([[Academy Award]] Winner) *''[[Five Corners (film)|Five Corners]]'' (1987) *''[[The January Man]]'' (1989) *''[[Joe Versus the Volcano]]'' (1990; directed by Shanley) *''[[Alive (1993 film)|Alive]]'' (1993) *''[[We're Back! A Dinosaur's Story (film)|We're Back! A Dinosaur's Story]]'' (1993) *''[[Congo (movie)|Congo]]'' (1995) *''[[Live from Baghdad (film)|Live From Baghdad]]'' (2002) (TV, Emmy nomination) *''[[The Waltz of the Tulips]]'' (2006) *''[[Doubt (2008 film)|Doubt]]'' (2008; directed by Shanley and adapted from his play of the same title) {{col-end}} ==Awards and nominations== ;Awards *1988 [[Academy Award]] for [[Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay|Best Original Screenplay]] – ''[[Moonstruck]]'' *2005 [[Drama Desk Award]] for Outstanding New Play – ''[[Doubt: A Parable]]'' *2005 [[Pulitzer Prize]] for Drama – ''Doubt: A Parable'' *2005 [[Tony Award]] for Best Play – ''Doubt: A Parable'' *2005 Lucille Lortel Award for Outstanding Play – ''Doubt: A Parable'' *2005 Drama Critics' Circle Award – ''Doubt: A Parable'' *2005 [[Obie Award]] for Playwriting – ''Doubt: A Parable'' ;Nominations *2003 [[Emmy Award]] for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Writing for a Miniseries, Movie or a Dramatic Special|Outstanding Writing for a Miniseries, or Dramatic Special]] – ''[[Live from Baghdad (film)|Live From Baghdad]]'' *2005 Drama Desk Award Outstanding New Play – ''Sailor's Song'' *2008 [[Golden Globe Award]] for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Screenplay|Best Screenplay]] – ''[[Doubt (2008 film)|Doubt]]'' *2008 [[Academy Award]] for [[Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay|Best Adapted Screenplay]] – ''[[Doubt (2008 film)|Doubt]]'' *2008 [[Critics' Choice Award]] for Writer – ''[[Doubt (2008 film)|Doubt]]'' ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IBDB name|392489}} *{{IMDb name|788234}} *{{iobdb name|John|Shanley|Patrick}} *{{OL author|OL60974A}} *[http://www.nytimes.com/2004/11/07/magazine/07SHANLEY.html John Patrick Shanley profile in ''The New York Times Magazine''] *[http://www.moviemaker.com/directing/article/john_patrick_shanley_doubt_meryl_streep_amy_adams_philip_seymour_hoffman_20/ MovieMaker] {{Infobox person | name = Christopher Durang | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1949|1|2}} | birth_place = [[Montclair, New Jersey]] | website = http://www.christopherdurang.com }} '''Christopher Ferdinand Durang''' (born January 2, 1949) is an [[United States|American]] [[playwright]] known for works of outrageous and often [[Theatre of the Absurd|absurd]] comedy. His work was especially popular in the 1980s. == Life == Durang was born in [[Montclair, New Jersey]], the son of Patricia Elizabeth, a secretary, and architect [[Francis Ferdinand Durang, Jr.]][http://www.filmreference.com/film/34/Christopher-Durang.html Biography] at FilmReference.com He grew up in Berkeley Heights, New Jersey. He attended [[Catholic school]]s as a child, including the Our Lady of Peace School in [[New Providence, New Jersey]] and the [[Delbarton School]] in [[Morristown, New Jersey]].Dunlap, LucyAnn. [http://www.princetoninfo.com/200508/50817p08.html "A Play That Asks, 'What Happens After?'"], ''U.S. 1 Newspaper'', August 17, 2005. Accessed May 12, 2007. "He wrote his first play at age eight. His Catholic grammar school cancelled class one afternoon and put on his play. Later while he was attending Delbarton School in Morristown, he and a friend wrote two musicals, "Banned in Boston" and "Businessman's Holiday." You won't find these in his collected works but they certainly suggest a young man with an active imagination and a penchant for writing." He received a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in [[English studies|English]] from [[Harvard]] and an [[Master of Fine Arts|M.F.A.]] in playwriting from [[Yale School of Drama]]. He lives in [[Bucks County]] with his partner, John Augustine; they have been together for more than 20 years.{{cite web |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2005/11/26/theater/newsandfeatures/26dura.html |title=Christopher Durang Explores the Afterlife, Including His Own |first=Dinithia |last=Smith |work=[[New York Times]] |date=2005-11-26 |accessdate=2007-05-11}} Durang is openly gay.{{cite news|title=Laugh Out Loud With Sigourney Weaver and Snow White|url=http://www.advocate.com/arts-entertainment/theater/seat-filler/2013/04/28/laugh-out-loud-sigourney-weaver-and-snow-white|date=April 28, 2013|work=[[The Advocate]]|first=Daniel|last=Villarreal}} == Work == His work often deals critically with issues of [[child abuse]], [[Roman Catholic]] [[dogma]] and culture, and [[homosexuality]]. While Durang's use of parody and his criticism of many social institutions might appear overly cynical at times, he states:
...when I say everyone is crazy that means it’s a very bad day where the amount of crazy people in the world has spread out to the entire universe and it doesn’t seem possible to cope with anything... I think we’re all neurotic. And I do think relationships are certainly difficult. Nonetheless, those lines in the play do get a laugh, so there’s something. It’s not as despairing as it sounds, but I don’t not believe it.Gholson, Craig. [http://bombsite.com/issues/20/articles/950 "Chris Durang Interview"] ''[[BOMB Magazine]]'' Summer, 1987. Retrieved May 17, 2013.
His plays have been performed nationwide, including on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] and [[Off-Broadway]].http://www.ibdb.com/person.asp?id=4832 "Internet Broadway Database: Christopher Durang Credits on Broadway" on IBDB His works include ''[[Sister Mary Ignatius Explains It All For You]]'', ''[[Beyond Therapy]]'', ''[[Baby With the Bathwater]]'', ''[[The Nature and Purpose of the Universe]]'', ''[[Titanic (play)|Titanic]]'', ''[[A History of the American Film]]'', ''[[The Idiots Karamazov]]'', ''[[The Marriage of Bette and Boo]]'', ''[[Laughing Wild]]'', ''[['Dentity Crisis]]'', ''[[The Actor's Nightmare]]'', ''[[The Vietnamization of New Jersey]]'', ''[[Betty's Summer Vacation]]'', ''[[Naomi in the Living Room]]'', ''[[Adrift in Macao]]'', ''[[Mrs. Bob Cratchit's Wild Christmas Binge]]'', ''[[Miss Witherspoon]]'', ''[[Why Torture is Wrong, and the People Who Love Them]]'', "Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike", and a collection of one-act parodies meant to be performed in one evening entitled ''[[Durang/Durang]]'' that includes "Mrs. Sorken", "For Whom The Southern Belle Tolls" (a parody of ''[[The Glass Menagerie]]'' by [[Tennessee Williams]]), "A Stye Of the Eye", "Nina in the Morning", "Wanda's Visit", and "Business Lunch at the Russian Tea Room". Durang has performed as an actor for both stage and screen. He first came to prominence in his [[Off-Broadway]] satirical review ''Das Lusitania Songspiel'', which he performed with friend and fellow Yale alum [[Sigourney Weaver]]. Later he co-starred in one of his own plays as Matt in ''The Marriage of Bette and Boo'', as well as Man in the original production of ''Laughing Wild''. === In film === Durang has denounced the [[Robert Altman]] 1987 [[Beyond Therapy (film)|film adaptation]] of ''[[Beyond Therapy]]'', calling it "horrific" and accusing Altman of totally rewriting the script "so that all psychology is thrown out the window, and the characters dash around acting crazy but with literally no behavioral logic underneath."{{Citation needed|date=October 2007}} Durang has appeared as an actor in the 1987 comedy ''[[The Secret of My Success (1987 film)|The Secret of My Success]]'', 1988's ''[[Mr. North]]'', 1989's ''[[Penn & Teller Get Killed]]'', 1992's ''[[HouseSitter]]'' and 1994's ''[[The Cowboy Way (film)|The Cowboy Way]]''. He has also written a number of unproduced [[screenplay]]s, including ''The Nun Who Shot Liberty Valance'', ''The House of Husbands'' (which he co-authored with [[Wendy Wasserstein]]), and ''The Adventures of Lola''. === On television === ''Wanda's Visit'', one of the six one-acts in ''Durang/Durang'' was originally written for the [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] series ''Trying Times'', and Durang played the part of The Waiter in that production.http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0734032/http://www.christopherdurang.com/OneActsLong-Belle-Stye-Wanda.htm == Awards and honors == He received [[Obie Awards]] for ''Sister Mary Ignatius'', ''The Marriage of Bette and Boo'' and ''Betty's Summer Vacation''. He received a nomination for a [[Tony Award for Best Book of a Musical]] for ''A History of the American Film''. Durang has been awarded numerous fellowships and high profile grants including a [[Guggenheim Fellowship|Guggenheim]], a Rockefeller, the CBS Playwriting Fellowship, the ''Lecomte du Nouy Foundation'' grant, and the ''Kenyon Festival Theatre Playwriting Prize''. He is a member of the [[Dramatists Guild]] Council, and is co-chair of the playwriting program at [[Juilliard]]. He was also a finalist for the [[Pulitzer Prize]] in Drama in 2006 for ''Miss Witherspoon''. On May 17, 2010 he was presented with the very first Luminary Award from the [[New York Innovative Theatre Awards]] for his work Off-Off-Broadway. He was awarded the [[PEN/Laura Pels International Foundation for Theater Award]] in 2012. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{official website|http://www.christopherdurang.com/}} * {{imdb name | id=0243837| name=Christopher Durang}} * [http://www.ibdb.com/person.asp?ID=4832 Christopher Durang] at the [http://www.ibdb.com/ Internet Broadway Database] * [http://www.tv.com/christopher-durang/person/31098/biography.html tv.com] * [http://www.americantheatrewing.org/downstagecenter/detail/christopher_durang Christopher Durang] - ''Downstage Center'' interview at [[American Theatre Wing|American Theatre Wing.org]] * [http://bombsite.com/issues/20/articles/950 ''BOMB Magazine'' interview with Christopher Durang by Craig Gholson (Summer, 1987)] {{Christopher Durang}} {{Authority control|VIAF=79044746}} {{Persondata | NAME =Durang, Christopher | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH =January 2, 1949 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[Montclair, New Jersey]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Durang, Christopher}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:American dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:American screenwriters]] [[Category:Delbarton School alumni]] [[Category:Former Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Gay writers]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:Juilliard School faculty]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Obie Award recipients]] [[Category:People from Berkeley Heights, New Jersey]] [[Category:People from Montclair, New Jersey]] [[Category:Yale School of Drama alumni]] [[Category:Writers from New Jersey]]

{{Infobox person | image = Nydia Westman.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date|1902|02|19}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], USA | death_date = {{dda|1970|05|23|1902|02|19}} | death_place = [[Burbank, California|Burbank]], [[California]] | death_cause =Cancer | resting_place = [[Oakwood Memorial Park Cemetery]] in [[Chatsworth, California|Chatsworth]], California | spouse = Robert Sparks (1930-1937) (divorced) 1 child | children = Kate Williamson | yearsactive = 1932–1970 }}
'''Nydia Eileen Westman''' (February 19, 1902 – May 23, 1970) was an American actress and singer of stage, screen and television.
==Career== Westman's career ranged from episodic appearances on TV [[sitcom]]s and uncredited bit roles in movies to appearances in groundbreaking films (such as ''[[Craig's Wife]]'', which starred [[Rosalind Russell]], and the first film version of ''[[Little Women]]'' which starred [[Katharine Hepburn]] in her first great movie success).
She appeared as the [[Housekeeper (servant)|housekeeper]] Mrs. Featherstone in the 1962–1963 [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] series, ''[[Going My Way (TV series)|Going My Way]]'', which starred [[Gene Kelly]] and [[Leo G. Carroll]] as [[Roman Catholic]] priests in [[New York City]]. [[Dick York]] was a series regular in the role of the operator of a neighborhood youth center.
She also broke ground on stage, debuting the role of "Nell" off-Broadway in [[Samuel Beckett]]'s ''[[Endgame (play)|Endgame]]'', for which she won one of the first [[Obie Award|Obie]] awards.
==Personal life== Westman's parents, Theodore and Lily (Wren) Westman were actors in [[vaudeville]] in her native New York City. Her sisters, Lolita and Neville were actresses, and her brother, Theodore (d. November 20, 1927), was an actor and [[playwright]].
She was married to Robert Sparkes, a producer, from 1930 until 1937; they had a daughter.
Westman died of [[cancer]] at the age of sixty-eight in [[Burbank, California|Burbank]], [[California]].

{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2012}} '''Cara Duff-MacCormick''' is a Canadian actress best known for her work within the American theatre.
==Career== Born in [[Woodstock, Ontario]], Duff-MacCormick studied acting at the [[American Academy of Dramatic Arts]] in New York City before making her professional debut [[Off-Broadway]] in December 1969 at the [[Cherry Lane Theatre]] as Faith Detweiler in Harold J. Chapler's ''Love Your Crooked Neighbor''. She made her Broadway debut as Shelly in [[Michael Weller]]'s ''[[Moonchildren]]'' in 1972, a role she had performed the year before at the [[Arena Stage]] in 1971.<ref>{{cite web|author=By MEL GUSSOWSpecial to The New York Times |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00B15F93B5C1A7493C4AB178AD95F458785F9&scp=2&sq=Cara+Duff-MacCormick&st=p |title=''New York Times'', November 26, 1971 |publisher=Select.nytimes.com |date=November 26, 1971 |accessdate=January 8, 2012}}</ref> For her performance she won a [[Theatre World Award]] and garnered a [[Tony Award]] nomination.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theatreworldawards.org/award.html |title=Theatre World Awards |publisher=Theatre World Awards |accessdate=January 8, 2012}}</ref> The following year she returned to Broadway to portray Clare in [[Tennessee Williams]]'s play ''[[Out Cry]]'' at the [[Lyceum Theatre (Broadway)|Lyceum Theatre]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Gussow |first=Mel |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F4071EFD3F54137A93C3A81788D85F478785F9&scp=4&sq=Cara+Duff-MacCormick&st=p |title=''New York Times'', March 11, 1973 |publisher=Select.nytimes.com |date=March 11, 1973 |accessdate=January 8, 2012}}</ref> and she portrayed the role of Nina in [[Anton Chekhov]]'s ''[[The Seagull]]'' at the [[McCarter Theatre]] in [[Princeton, New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite web|author=By CLIVE BARNESSpecial to The New York Times |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70817FB3D5D127A93CAA9178BD95F478785F9&scp=6&sq=Cara+Duff-MacCormick&st=p |title=''New York Times'', October 8, 1973 |publisher=Select.nytimes.com |date=October 8, 1973 |accessdate=January 8, 2012}}</ref> In 1975 she won an [[Obie Award]] for her performance in ''Craig's Wife''.
In 1976 Duff-MacCormick was nominated for a [[Drama Desk Award]] for her portrayal of Julia Craven in [[George Bernard Shaw]]'s ''[[The Philanderer]]'' with the [[Roundabout Theatre Company]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Barnes |first=Clive |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20910F63E5B167493C2AA1782D85F428785F9&scp=9&sq=Cara+Duff-MacCormick&st=p |title=''New York Times'', September 30, 1976 |publisher=Select.nytimes.com |date=September 30, 1976 |accessdate=January 8, 2012}}</ref> That same year she portrayed the role of Helen in [[Kevin O'Morrison]]'s ''[[Ladyhouse Blues]]'' at the [[Marymount Manhattan Theatre]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Barnes |first=Clive |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20D12FA395B167493C6A9178AD95F428785F9&scp=11&sq=Cara+Duff-MacCormick&st=p |title=''New York Times'', November 4, 1976 |publisher=Select.nytimes.com |date=November 4, 1976 |accessdate=January 8, 2012}}</ref> and portrayed the role of Tammy Ulrich in the film ''[[All the President's Men (film)|All the President's Men]]''. In 1977 she starred in [[Albert Innaurato]]'s ''[[Earthworms (play)|Earthworms]]'' at the [[Playwrights Horizons]] theatre alongside [[Jonathan Frakes]] and [[David Keith]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Gussow |first=Mel |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10917F73E5F15768FDDAE0A94DD405B878BF1D3&scp=12&sq=Cara+Duff-MacCormick&st=p |title=''New York Times'', May 27, 1977 |publisher=Select.nytimes.com |date=May 27, 1977 |accessdate=January 8, 2012}}</ref> In 1978 she portrayed the role of Hakon's wife in [[Henrik Ibsen]]'s ''[[The Pretenders (play)|The Pretenders]]'' alongside [[Randall Duk Kim]] and [[Stephen Lang (actor)|Stephen Lang]] at the [[Guthrie Theater]] in [[Minneapolis]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Eder |first=Richard |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60B12FC3D5413728DDDAD0A94DF405B888BF1D3&scp=14&sq=Cara+Duff-MacCormick&st=p |title=''New York Times'', July 24, 1978 |publisher=Select.nytimes.com |date=July 24, 1978 |accessdate=January 8, 2012}}</ref> That same year she portrayed the role of Agafya Tikhonovna in [[Nikolai Gogol]]'s ''[[Marriage (play)|Marriage]]'' with [[Peter Michael Goetz]] as Ivan Kuzmich Podkolyossin and [[Barbara Bryne]] as Fyokla Ivanovna, also at the Guthrie Theatre.<ref>{{cite web|last=Eder |first=Richard |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0817F73D5511728DDDAD0994D9415B888BF1D3&scp=16&sq=Cara+Duff-MacCormick&st=p |title=''New York Times'', November 14, 1978 |publisher=Select.nytimes.com |date=November 14, 1978 |accessdate=January 8, 2012}}</ref> Duff-MacCormick also appeared frequently at [[The Repertory Theatre of St. Louis]] during the 1970s, including portraying the roles of Mrs. Sullen in [[George Farquhar]]'s ''[[The Beaux' Stratagem]]'' (1976), Bananas in [[John Guare]]'s ''[[The House of Blue Leaves]]'' (1977), Judith Anderson in [[George Bernard Shaw]]'s ''[[The Devil's Disciple]]'' (1977) and Sister Rita in ''[[The Runner Stumbles]]'' (1978).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.repstl.org/productionhistory/results/4d6e2ddf0d75c0a9c03bcb4c73f3cc81/ |title=The Repertory Theatre of St. Louis Performance Archives |publisher=Repstl.org |accessdate=January 8, 2012}}</ref>
In 1980 Duff-MacCormick portrayed the role of Monique in [[Michel Tremblay]]'s ''[[Bonjour, La, Bonjour]]'' at the Marymount Manhattan Theatre alongside [[Veronica Castang]] and [[Dianne Wiest]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Rich |first=Frank |url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0A14FE3D5E12728DDDAD0994D8415B8084F1D3&scp=18&sq=Cara+Duff-MacCormick&st=p |title=''New York Times'', October 14, 1980 |publisher=Select.nytimes.com |date=October 14, 1980 |accessdate=January 8, 2012}}</ref> The following year she returned to Broadway to appear in [[Eddie Lawrence]]'s ''Animals'' at the [[Princess Theatre]]. In 1982 she portrayed the role of Peggy Grant in ''[[The Front Page]]''<ref>[http://theater2.nytimes.com/mem/theater/treview.html?res=9E04EED81F38F933A25755C0A964948260&scp=9&sq=Cara+Duff-MacCormick&st=nyt ''New York Times'', June 10, 1982]</ref> and in 1983 she portrayed the role of Carrie in [[Paul Kember]]'s ''[[Not Quite Jerusalem]]'', both at the [[Long Wharf Theater]].<ref>[http://theater2.nytimes.com/mem/theater/treview.html?res=9E04E1D61438F936A15751C1A965948260&scp=7&sq=Cara+Duff-MacCormick&st=nyt ''New York Times'', December 25, 1983]</ref> In 1985 she appeared Off-Broadway at the [[American Theater Exchange]] as Claire in [[Heather McDonald]]'s ''Faulkner's Bicycle''<ref>[http://theater2.nytimes.com/mem/theater/treview.html?res=9906E7D81239F935A25755C0A963948260&scp=5&sq=Cara+Duff-MacCormick&st=nyt ''New York Times'', June 16, 1986]</ref> and she appeared at the [[Actors Theatre of Louisville]] in the role of Carolyn Rose in [[Lee Blessing]]'s ''[[War of the Roses]]'' opposite [[Paul Collins (actor)|Paul Collins]].<ref>[http://www.actorstheatre.org/HUMANA%20FESTIVAL%20CDROM/war.htm Actors Theatre, Louisville]{{dead link|date=January 2012}}</ref> This was followed by a portrayal of Barbara Mears in [[Tom Strelich]]'s ''Neon Psalms'' at the [[American Place Theatre]] in 1986.<ref>[http://theater2.nytimes.com/mem/theater/treview.html?res=9A0DE1DE1239F930A15753C1A960948260&scp=4&sq=Cara+Duff-MacCormick&st=nyt ''New York Times'', October 23, 1986]</ref> In 1987 she appeared at the [[Hartford Stage]] as Barbara in [[A. R. Gurney]]'s ''[[Children (play)|Children]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE7DA1F3DF932A35751C0A961948260&scp=3&sq=Cara+Duff-MacCormick&st=nyt |title=''New York Times'', February 1, 1987 |work=New York Times |date=February 1, 1987 |accessdate=January 8, 2012}}</ref> She returned to the Playwrights Horizons in 1989 to perform the role of Natalie Bauer Lechner in Albert Innaurato's ''[[Gus and Al]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=950DE1D61131F93BA15751C0A96F948260&scp=2&sq=Cara+Duff-MacCormick&st=nyt |title=''New York Times'', February 28, 1989 |work=New York Times |date=February 28, 1989 |accessdate=January 8, 2012}}</ref>
In 1992 she portrayed the role of Queen Isabella in [[Christopher Marlowe]]'s ''[[Edward II (play)|Edward II]]'' at the [[Yale Repertory Theatre]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CEEDD163DF936A35757C0A964958260&scp=1&sq=Cara+Duff-MacCormick&st=nyt |title=''New York Times'', April 5, 1992 |work=New York Times |date=April 5, 1992 |accessdate=January 8, 2012}}</ref> That same year she appeared in a guest-starring role on ''[[Law & Order]]'' in the episode "[[Point of View (Law & Order episode)|Point of View]]".
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
== External links == *{{IMDb name|0240422}} *{{ibdb name|id=88015|name=Cara Duff-MacCormick}} *[http://www.lortel.org/lla_archive/index.cfm?search_by=people&first=Cara&middle=&last=Duff-MacCormick Cara Duff-MacCormick at the Internet Off Broadway Database]

{{BLP sources|date=November 2009}}
'''Marshall W. Mason''' (born February 24, 1940) is an [[United States|American]] [[theater director]],<ref>"[[Who's Who in the World: 2010]]"</ref> the founder and for eighteen years, artistic director of the [[Circle Repertory Company]] in [[New York City]].
Born in [[Amarillo, Texas]], Mason graduated from [[Northwestern University]], where he directed ''[[Cat on a Hot Tin Roof]]'' at the age of 19.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=yZdQAAAAMAAJ&dq=%27%27Creating+Life+On+Stage:+A+Director%27s+Approach+to+Working+with+Actors%27%27&ie=ISO-8859-1&output=html ''Creating Life On Stage'' at Google Books]</ref> He relocated to [[Manhattan]], where he began working in the [[off-off-Broadway]] theater scene in such venues as [[Caffe Cino]],<ref>"[[Return to the Caffe Cino: A Collection of Plays and Memoirs]]", edited by Stephen Susoyev and George Birimisa</ref> the [[La MaMa Experimental Theatre Club]], and [[Judson Poets Theatre]]. He made his [[off-Broadway]] debut in 1964 with a revival of the [[Henrik Ibsen]] play ''[[Little Eyolf]]''.<ref>[[The New York Times]], March 17, 1963</ref> The following year he directed ''[[Balm in Gilead]]'', his first collaboration with playwright [[Lanford Wilson]]. Since then he has directed more than sixty productions of Wilson's plays, which [[Playbill]] has identified as the longest collaboration between a playwright and director in the history of the American theater. Among these are ''[[The Hot l Baltimore]]'', for which he won his first [[Obie Award]] for Distinguished Direction, ''[[Fifth of July]]'', ''[[Talley's Folly]]'', and ''[[Burn This]].''<ref>[http://www.lortel.org/lla_archive/index.cfm?search_by=people&first=Marshall&middle=W.&last=Mason] at the Lortel Archives]</ref>
Mason has directed twelve productions on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] and has been nominated for the [[Tony Award for Best Direction of a Play]] five times,<ref>"[[The Tony Award: A Complete Listing]]", edited by Isabelle Stevens</ref> and the [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Director of a Play]] twice. His first [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] production was the 1976 play ''Knock Knock'' by [[Jules Feiffer]], for which he received his first Tony nomination. Additional Broadway credits include ''[[Gemini (play)|Gemini]]'', ''[[Fifth of July]]'', ''[[Talley's Folly]]'', ''[[Angels Fall]]'', ''[[As Is (play)|As Is]]'', ''[[Burn This]]'', ''[[The Seagull]]'', and ''[[Redwood Curtain]]''. [[Off-Broadway]] he was awarded five Obies for Outstanding Direction and a sixth Obie Award for Sustained Achievement. Memorable off-Broadway productions he directed include ''The Sea Horse'', ''Talley & Son'', ''Sunshine'', ''Serenading Louie'', ''Childe Byron'', ''The Destiny of Me'', and the New York premiere of [[Tennessee Williams]]'s ''[[Battle of Angels]]''. He is the recipient of the 1979 [[Theatre World Award]],<ref>[http://www.theatreworldawards.org/past-recipients.html]",</ref> and the 1977 [[Margo Jones]] Award<ref> "[http://library.osu.edu/find/collections/theatre-research-institute/margo-jones-award/margo-jones-award-recipients/]"</ref> for his work with the Circle Repertory Company, and a 1999 "Mr. Abbott Special Millennium Award" as one of the most innovative and influential directors of the twentieth century.<ref>[http://www.sdcweb.org/foundation/the-mr-abbott-award//]</ref>
He has worked widely in [[regional theater]]s, including the [[Mark Taper Forum]] in [[Los Angeles]], the [[Guthrie Theater]] in [[Minneapolis]], the [[Steppenwolf Theater]] in [[Chicago]], [[Arena Stage]] and [[Ford's Theater]] in [[Washington, D.C.]], the [[McCarter Theater]] in [[Princeton, New Jersey|Princeton]], the [[Hartford Stage Company]], the [[Pittsburgh Public Theater]], the [[Repertory Theater of St. Louis]], the [[Cincinnati Playhouse]], and the [[Milwaukee Rep]]. For one season (1988), he was Guest Artistic Director for the [[Ahmanson Theater]] of the Los Angeles Center Theater Group. In addition, he directed three productions in [[London]] and ''[[Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?]]'' at the [[National Theatre of Japan]] in [[Tokyo]]. For television, he directed ''[[Picnic (play)| Picnic]]'', ''The Mound Builders'', ''Kennedy's Children'', and ''[[Fifth of July]]''.
Mason is [[Professor Emeritus]] of Theater at [[Arizona State University]],<ref>[http://herbergerinstitute.asu.edu/news/press_release.php?id=184] </ref> where he taught for ten years, and was honored with ASU’s 2001 Creative Activity Award. He is the author of the 2007 book ''Creating Life On Stage: A Director's Approach to Working with Actors''.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=yZdQAAAAMAAJ&dq=%27%27Creating+Life+On+Stage:+A+Director%27s+Approach+to+Working+with+Actors%27%27&ie=ISO-8859-1&output=html ''Creating Life On Stage'' at Google Books]</ref> He divides his time between his homes in [[Mazatlán]] and [[Manhattan]]. On 25 July 2011, the first Monday after [[New York State]] enacted its [[marriage equality]] law, Mason married his long-time companion and fellow theater artist, Daniel Irvine,<ref>[[New York Post]], July 25, 2011: "Wed at Last"</ref>
==Additional directing credits== *''[[Home Free!]]'' (1965) *''[[The Madness of Lady Bright]]'' (1968) *''The Gingham Dog'' (1968) *''[[Three Sisters (play)|Three Sisters]]'' (1970) *''The Sea Horse'' (1974) *''Battle of Angels'' (1974) *''The Mound Builders'' (1975) *''Serenading Louie'' (1976) *''[[Murder at the Howard Johnson's]]'' (1979) *''[[Angels Fall]]'' (1983) *''[[Passion (play)|Passion]]'' (1983) *''[[Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?]]'' (1985) *''Sunshine'' (1989) *''[[The Destiny of Me]]'' (1992) *''A Poster of the Cosmos'' (1994) *''The Moonshot Tape'' (1994) *''Cakewalk'' (1996) *''Robbers'' (1997) *''Sympathetic Magic'' (1997) *''[[Long Day's Journey into Night]]'' (1998) *''Book of Days'' (2002) *''[[The Goat, or Who is Sylvia?]]'' (2007)

{{ref improve|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Joan Hackett | image = Joan_hackett.jpg | caption = Joan Hackett in ''The Twilight Zone''
episode "A Piano in the House" (1962) | birthname = Joan Ann Hackett | birth_date = {{Birth date|1934|3|1|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[East Harlem]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)| New York]], USA | death_date = {{Death date and age|1983|10|8|1934|3|1|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Encino, California|Encino]], [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], [[California]] | death_cause =[[Ovarian cancer]] | resting_place =[[Hollywood Forever Cemetery]] | spouse = [[Richard Mulligan]]
(1967-1973) (divorced) | yearsactive = 1959–1983 | occupation = Actress }} '''Joan Ann Hackett''' (March 1, 1934 – October 8, 1983) was an American actress who appeared on stage, films, and television.Obituary ''[[Variety Obituaries|Variety]]'', October 12, 1983. == Early life == She was born in [[New York City]] of [[Irish American|Irish]] and [[Italian American|Italian]] extraction. Her immigrant parents reared her [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] and sent her to [[parochial school|Catholic schools]].{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1964&dat=19781209&id=LvEiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5ssFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5875,6764368|title=The Palm Beach Post|work=www.news.google.com}} == Acting career == Hackett debuted in 1959 with the role of Gail Prentiss in the [[television series]], ''[[Young Doctor Malone]]''. In 1961 she won a [[Theatre World Award]], an [[Obie Award]], and a [[Drama Desk Award]] for her portrayal of Chris in [[Michael Shurtleff]]'s play ''[[Call Me By My Rightful Name]]''. She had a recurring role on the [[CBS]] legal drama ''[[The Defenders (1961 TV series)|The Defenders]]'' (1961–1965) as the fiancee of Kenneth Preston (played by [[Robert Reed]]), partner in the father-and-son law firm led by patriarch Lawrence Preston ([[E.G. Marshall]]). She appeared regularly in scenes with both lead actors. She had a leading role in ''[[The Twilight Zone (1959 TV series)|The Twilight Zone]]'' episode "[[A Piano in the House]]". In the 1963-1964 season, she guest starred on the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] [[drama]] about [[college]] life, ''[[Channing (TV series)|Channing]]'' starring [[Jason Evers]] and [[Henry Jones (actor)|Henry Jones]]. Hackett had one of the starring roles in the 1966 [[Sidney Lumet]] film ''[[The Group (film)|The Group]]'', along with [[Candice Bergen]], [[Larry Hagman]], [[Richard Mulligan]], [[Joanna Pettet]] and others. One of her notable movie performances was the role of Catherine Allen, a young mother struggling to survive on the frontier, in the 1968 [[Western (genre)|Western]] ''[[Will Penny]]'', with [[Charlton Heston]] in the title role. Hackett also had notable parts in the classic Western comedy ''[[Support Your Local Sheriff!]]'', with [[James Garner]], and the 1973 murder mystery ''[[The Last of Sheila]]''. After this she primarily had parts in TV movies and on episodes of TV series. Hackett won the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actress - Motion Picture]] and was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress]] for her performance in the 1981 movie ''[[Only When I Laugh (film)|Only When I Laugh]]'', the last movie she made before her death. She could also be seen in [[Paul Simon]]'s film ''[[One-Trick Pony (film)|One Trick Pony]]''. == Personal life == From 1965 to 1973 she was married to actor [[Richard Mulligan]], who also appeared in ''The Group''. == Death == Hackett died in 1983 of [[ovarian cancer]] at Encino Hospital in [[Encino, California|Encino]], in [[California]]. Both of her parents as well as her former husband Richard Mulligan also died of cancer. She is interred at [[Hollywood Forever Cemetery]], where her [[epitaph]] reads "Go Away—I'm Asleep", a reference to her love of [[wikt:beauty sleep|beauty sleep]]. == Partial filmography == * 1966: ''[[The Group (film)|The Group]]'' * 1968: ''[[Will Penny]]'' * 1968: ''[[Assignment to Kill]]'' * 1969: ''[[Support Your Local Sheriff!]]'' * 1970: ''The Other Man'' * 1970: ''[[The Young Country]]'' * 1970: ''[[How Awful About Allan]]'' * 1971: ''[[Five Desperate Women]]'' * 1972: ''Lights Out'' * 1973: ''[[The Last of Sheila]]'' * 1974: ''[[Reflections of Murder]]'' * 1974: ''[[The Terminal Man]]'' * 1975: ''[[Mackintosh & T.J.]]'' * 1976: ''[[Treasure of Matecumbe]]'' * 1977: ''Dead of Night'' * 1977: ''[[The Possessed (1977 film)|The Possessed]]'' * 1980: ''[[The Long Days of Summer]]'' * 1980: ''[[One-Trick Pony (film)|One Trick Pony]]'' * 1980: ''[[Harnessing the Sun]]'' * 1981: ''[[Only When I Laugh (film)|Only When I Laugh]]'' * 1982: ''[[The Escape Artist]]'' === Selected television guest appearances === * 1960 ''[[Diagnosis: Unknown]]'' in "Gina, Gina" (episode 1.7) September 6 * 1962 ''[[The New Breed (TV series)|The New Breed]]'' (1961) playing Angie in episode: "Cross the Little Line" (episode #1.15) January 9 * 1962 ''[[The Twilight Zone (1959 TV series)|The Twilight Zone]]'' (1959) playing "Esther Fortune" in episode: "[[A Piano in the House]]" (episode # 3.22) February 16 * 1962 ''[[Gunsmoke]]'' (1955) playing "Mady Arthur" in episode: "The Widow" (episode # 7.25) March 24 * 1963 ''[[Combat!]]'' (1962) playing "Gabrielle" in episode: "The Chateau" (episode # 1.19) February 12 * 1963 ''[[Empire (1962 TV series)|Empire]]'' (1962) playing Dolores Lanza in episode: "Between Friday and Monday" (episode # 1.31) May 7 *1964 ''[[Channing (TV series)|Channing]]'' (1963) playing Djuna Phrayne in episode: "A Rich, Famous, Glamorous Folk Singer Like Me" (episode # 1.15) January 8 * 1964 ''[[The Alfred Hitchcock Hour]]'' (1962) playing "Helen Clarvoe" in episode: "Beast in View" (episode # 2.21) March 20 * 1965 ''[[Bonanza]]'' (1959) playing "Margarita Miguel" in episode: "Woman of Fire" (episode # 6.17) January 17 * 1966 ''[[Run for Your Life (TV series)|Run for Your Life]]'' (1965) playing Diana Murrow in episode: "The Sex Object" (episode # 2.6) October 17 * 1967 ''[[Judd, for the Defense]]'' (1967) playing Ruth Massey in episode: "The Living Victim" (episode # 1.14) December 15 * 1969 ''[[Daniel Boone (TV series)|Daniel Boone]]'' (1964) playing "Theodora Liggett" in episode: "A Pinch of Salt" (episode #5.26) May 1 * 1971 ''[[Dan August]] (1970) playing Nancy Williams in "The Assassins" (episode # 1.26) April 8 * 1979 ''[[Trapper John, M.D.]]'' (1979) playing "Wilma" in episode: "The Surrogate" (episode # 1.10) December 23 * 1979 ''[[Taxi (TV series)|Taxi]]'' playing "Charlotte", the sister of "Alex Reiger" in episode: "Honor Thy Father" (season 2, episode 2) aired on 18 September 1979 * 1982 '' [[Paper Dolls]]'' (1982) playing "Julia Blake" mother of teen model Taryn Blake {{Portal box|Biography|New York|California|Theatre|Film|Television}} ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb name|0352466}} * [http://www.allmovie.com/cg/avg.dll?p=avg&sql=1:198368~C Allmovie Review of her episode of ''The Twilight Zone''] * [http://www.jodavidsmeyer.com/combat/episodes/chateau.html Review of her episode of ''Combat!''] * [http://www.allmovie.com/cg/avg.dll?p=avg&sql=1:234137~C Allmovie Plot synopsis of her 1965 ''Bonanza'' episode] * {{Find a Grave|1447}} {{GoldenGlobeBestSuppActressMotionPicture 1981-2000}} {{Persondata | NAME =Hackett, Joan | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH =March 1, 1934 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[East Harlem]], [[New York City, New York]], USA | DATE OF DEATH =October 8, 1983 | PLACE OF DEATH =[[Encino, California]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hackett, Joan}} [[Category:1934 births]] [[Category:1983 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century American actresses]] [[Category:American film actresses]] [[Category:American stage actresses]] [[Category:American television actresses]] [[Category:American Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Best Supporting Actress Golden Globe (film) winners]] [[Category:Burials at Hollywood Forever Cemetery]] [[Category:Cancer deaths in California]] [[Category:Deaths from ovarian cancer]] [[Category:Drama Desk Award winners]] [[Category:American people of Irish descent]] [[Category:American people of Italian descent]] [[Category:Obie Award recipients]] [[Category:People from New York City]] [[Category:People from Los Angeles, California]] [[Category:Theatre World Award winners]]

{{About||the 2010 film|Yellow Face (film)}} {{See also|Portrayal of East Asians in Hollywood}} {{Infobox play | name = Yellow Face | image = | image_size = | caption = | writer = [[David Henry Hwang]] | characters = DHH
Marcus G. Dahlman
Leah Anne Cho
HYH
[[Stuart Ostrow]] and others | setting = New York and California | premiere = December 10, 2007 | place = [[Mark Taper Forum]] | orig_lang = English | subject = Culture/Race | genre = Drama | iobdb_id = 5091 }} '''''Yellow Face''''' (2007) is a play by [[David Henry Hwang]], featuring the author himself as the protagonist. It premiered in Los Angeles at the [[Mark Taper Forum]] in association with [[East West Players]] and had its [[Off-Broadway]] premiere at the [[Joseph Papp Public Theater]].http://www.nytheatre.com/nytheatre/yell6060.htm Review by nytheate, 2007http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117933715.html?categoryid=33&cs=1 Review by Variety, 2007 Mixing fact and fiction, ''Yellow Face'' is partly autobiographical, with the character Hwang putting on Hwang's play, ''[[Face Value (play)|Face Value]]''. ''Yellow Face'' is a satire that raises deep questions of what race really means, how politics and media function in society, what America really stands for, the importance of both fact and fiction, and who we are. Mr. Hwang talks about Yellow Face at this event. [http://onlinecourses.colgate.edu/livingwriters] In 2008, it was revealed that ''Yellow Face'' gave Hwang his third Obie Award in Playwriting and made him a third-time finalist for the Pulitzer Prize for Drama. The play is currently published by [[Theatre Communications Group]] and in an acting edition by [[Dramatists Play Service]], Inc. ==Plot summary== When the musical ''[[Miss Saigon]]'' transferred from London to New York City, there was a [[Miss_Saigon#Controversy|controversy]] over the casting of [[Jonathan Pryce]], a white British actor, in an Asian role. Although Hwang receives a lot of publicity about his protests against the casting, particularly as the first Asian-American playwright to win a Tony (for ''[[M. Butterfly]]''), the production of ''Miss Saigon'' continues without changes to the cast. In the play ''Yellow Face'', the character Hwang accidentally casts a white man, Marcus G. Dahlman, as an Asian in one of the leading roles of ''Face Value''. Comedy ensues as Hwang is first convinced and then tries to convince other people that Marcus has Asian ancestry as a Jew from Siberia. Hwang realizes that Marcus has no Asian blood, but by then, ''Face Value'' has cost $2 million and Hwang tries to cover up his mistake. Marcus, however, continues playing his role as an Asian in all parts of his life, becoming an activist for Asian rights, angering Hwang who views him as an "ethnic tourist." The play further explores his relationship to his father and that of the Chinese community to America. The father is a successful immigrant who built a large bank in California, and after some political contributions, gets investigated by Sen. [[Fred Thompson]] as a Chinese who funnels money from China to influence American politics. The investigations bears resemblance to that of [[Wen Ho Lee]]. In the course of this, the protagonist and Marcus get implicated as Chinese collaborators. As Marcus' true identity reveals him as Caucasian, Thompsons's investigation breaks down, but Hwang now has to come clean about Marcus, and about himself. ==See also== *[[Portrayal of East Asians in Hollywood]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{David Henry Hwang}} [[Category:Plays by David Henry Hwang]] [[Category:Obie Award recipients]] [[Category:2007 plays]] [[Category:Off-Broadway plays]] [[Category:Satirical plays]] [[Category:Plays based on actual events]] [[Category:Plays about race and ethnicity]] [[Category:Asian-American plays]] [[Category:Plays set in New York City]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox musical artist | name = Diedre Murray | image = | alt = | caption = | image_size = | landscape = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank --> | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | birth_place = | origin = | death_date = <!-- {{death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date 1st) --> | death_place = | genre = [[Jazz]], [[classical music|classical]] | occupation = | instrument = [[Cello]] | years_active = 1970s–present<ref name="allmusicbio" /> | label = | associated_acts = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | notable_instruments = }} '''Diedre Murray''' (born November 28, 1951, [[Brooklyn]], [[New York]]<ref name="allmusicbio">{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p108445}}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=August 2011}}) is an [[United States|American]] [[Cello|cellist]] and composer specializing in [[jazz]], [[improvised music]], opera, and [[contemporary classical music]]. She is also active as a producer, and curator. She lives in [[Queens]], New York.
As a performer she has worked with the [[Henry Threadgill]] Sextett, [[Leroy Jenkins (jazz musician)|Leroy Jenkins]], [[Julius Hemphill]], [[James Brown]], [[Muhal Richard Abrams]], [[Archie Shepp]], [[Fred Hopkins]], [[Jason Kao Hwang]], and [[Hannibal (musician)|Marvin "Hannibal" Peterson]], in addition to leading a number of her own ensembles.
==Biography== In 1993 Murray received commissions to create: a score for the inaugural concert at the Danny Kaye/Sylvia Fine Playhouse entitled "Five Minute Tango," performed by the [[Manhattan Brass Quintet]]; ''The Conversation'' for the Seattle-based New Performance Group at the [[Walker Art Center]] in Minnesota for the Music in Motion program; ''Flashes'', a structured improvised collaboration with choreographer [[Blondell Cummings]] and musicians Jeanne Lee and [[Pauline Oliveros]] for The Firewall Festival 1993; and, music for [[Helen Thorington]]'s radio piece ''Dracula's Wives'' for broadcast.
In 1994, Murray's works included ''The Voice Within'', an a cappella theater piece for ten voices with text by Marcus Gardley, at [[Aaron Davis Hall]]; a tour of ''Flashes'' to the [[Taklos Festival]] in Switzerland; and, a dramatized version of ''Unending Pain'', with text by Laurie Carlos, at [[P.S. 122]] in New York City. Her work as a composer was intermixed with an extensive concert schedule as a band leader and concert soloist.
In 1996 her projects included: ''You Don't Miss the Water'', a music-theater piece, in collaboration with noted poet [[Cornelius Eady]], produced by the Music Theatre Group; and the premiere of ''Women In The Dunes'', a dance piece created by Blondel Cummings for the [[Japan Society]] and Mu Lan-Pi. Her dance theatrescape commissioned by District Curators and performed in [[Washington, D.C.]] by The Ajax Moving Dance Company.
In 1998 Murray developed the highly acclaimed jazz opera ''Running Man'', for which she wrote the original story, score, and book with collaborators Cornelius Eady and [[Diane Paulus]]. Murray won an [[Obie Award|Obie]] for her score and, with Eady, was a finalist for the 1999 [[Pulitzer Prize]] for Drama. Murray also conceived ''Songbird: The Life and Times of [[Ella Fitzgerald]]'', for which she wrote the original music. She received a grant from [[The Commissioning Project]] to write ''Eleven Elements of Joy'' for orchestra, which debuted in June 1999. In 2000 she wrote a new chamber and choral piece for The Commissioning Project.
In 2001 she wrote the music arrangements for the musical ''Eli's Coming'', for which she won her second Obie. In 2002 she composed the score for ''Brutal Imagination'', a verse play by Cornelius Eady. Other works include ''Strings Attached'', a dance piece by choreographer Risa Jaroslow; ''Best of Both Worlds'' created by Randy Weiner and Diane Paulus; and a collaboration with Sonoko Kawahara on ''Name of The Flower'', a music-theater piece; ''The Iliad'' and ''The Odyssey'' with [[Kathryn Walker]].
Murray collaborated with [[Diane Paulus]] on the musical ''[[The Best of Both Worlds (musical)|The Best of Both Worlds]]''. Recent projects include a collaboration with [[Carl Hancock Rux]] on ''The Blackamoor Angel'', a full length opera, a collaboration with Pulitzer Prize winner [[Lynn Nottage]] on a musical for children's musical entitled ''Sweet Billy and the Zooloos'', and year-long residency at Harlem Stages with playwright Marcus Gardley.
Murray is married to Lawrence Murray, Vice President and Director of Youth Programs at The National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at [[Columbia University]]. Murray is currently managed by Abram's Artists Agency.
==Discography== ===As leader=== *1992 - ''Firestorm'' *1993 - ''Stringology'' ([[Black Saint Records]], with [[Fred Hopkins]])
===As sidewoman=== '''With [[Henry Threadgill]]''' *''[[Just the Facts and Pass the Bucket]]'' (1983) *''[[Subject to Change (Henry Threadgill album)|Subject to Change]]'' (1985) *''[[You Know the Number]]'' (1986) *''[[Easily Slip Into Another World]]'' (1987) *''[[Rag, Bush and All]]'' (1988) '''With [[Muhal Richard Abrams]]''' *''[[The Hearinga Suite]]'' (1989)
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.deeplistening.org/site/catalog/Murray Diedre Murray bio]

revision.text:
{{Infobox play | name = Ruined | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | writer = [[Lynn Nottage]] | chorus = | characters = | mute = | setting = [[Democratic Republic of Congo]] | premiere = {{Start date|2007|MM}} | place = [[Goodman Theatre]] | orig_lang = English | series = | subject = | genre = | web = | playbill = | ibdb_id = | iobdb_id = 5201 | theatricalia_id = }}
'''''Ruined''''' is a play by [[Lynn Nottage]]. The play won the 2009 [[Pulitzer Prize for Drama]].<ref>Gans, Andrew and Jones, Kenneth.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/128443-Lynn_Nottage%27s_Ruined_Wins_Pulitzer_Prize_for_Drama_ "Lynn Nottage's Ruined Wins Pulitzer Prize for Drama"], playbill.com, April 20, 2009</ref><ref>[http://www.goodmantheatre.org/Season/ruined_pulitzer.aspx "Lynn Nottage Earns the 2009 Pulitzer Prize in Drama for Ruined"], goodmantheatre.org, accessed May 13, 2009</ref> The play involves the plight of women in the civil war-torn [[Democratic Republic of Congo]].
==Production history== ''Ruined'' was commissioned by the [[Goodman Theatre]] (Chicago, Illinois) and is a co-production with the [[Manhattan Theatre Club]]. Nottage and director [[Kate Whoriskey]] traveled to Uganda to interview women as background for the play, which first was performed in 2007 in the Goodman Theatre New Stages Series.<ref>[http://www.goodmantheatre.org/News/PressRoom/Releases/101608_RuinedRelease.aspx News Release, Ruined]''Goodman Theatre'', October 16, 2008</ref> The play premiered in November 2008 at the Goodman Theatre and ran through December 7. It opened off-Broadway at the [[Manhattan Theatre Club]], New York City Center – Stage I in previews on January 21, 2009, and officially on February 10, 2009. The production closed on September 6, 2009 after receiving nine extensions.<ref>Jones, Kenneth.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/128784-Pulitzer_Winner_Ruined_Gets_Six_Extra_Weeks_at_MTC Pulitzer Winner Ruined Gets Six Extra Weeks at MTC"], playbill.com, April 30, 2009</ref>
Both productions were directed by [[Kate Whoriskey]], with a cast that included Quincy Tyler Bernstine, Cherise Boothe, Condola Rashad, Chiké Johnson, Kevin Mambo, William Jackson Harper, Chris Chalk, Russell G. Jones, Tom Mardirosian, Ron McBee, Simon Shabantu Kashama and Saidah Arrika Ekulona (Mama Nadi) who left the production in May 2009 and was replaced by Portia. Scenic design was by [[Derek McLane]], costume design by [[Paul Tazewell]], lighting design by [[Peter Kaczorowski]], sound design by Rob Milburn and Michael Bodeen, and original music by Dominic Kanza with lyrics by Lynn Nottage.<ref>Jones, Kenneth.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/126205-After_a_Raft_of_Raves_Ruined_Gets_Two-Week_Extension_in_NYC After a Raft of Raves, Ruined Gets Two-Week Extension in NYC"], playbill.com, February 11, 2009</ref>
The European premiere of ''Ruined'', directed by [[Indhu Rubasingham]], opened for previews on April 15, 2010 with press night on April 22, 2010 at The Almeida Theatre in [[London]]. It closed on June 5, 2010. The cast included [[Jenny Jules]], [[Lucian Msamati]], [[Pippa Bennett-Warner]], Michelle Asante, Kehinde Fadipe, Okezie Morro, Silas Carson, David Ajala, Joel Kangudi, Steve Toussaint and Damola Adelaja. [[Jenny Jules]] won the 2010 [[Critics' Circle Theatre Award]] for Best Actress for her performance in this production.
''Ruined'' ran during the [[Oregon Shakespeare Festival]] in 2010.
It ran at the [[Denver Center for the Performing Arts]] through April 30, 2011.
==Critical response== [[Ben Brantley]] in his ''[[The New York Times]]'' review, wrote: "Ms. Nottage, the wide-ranging and increasingly confident author of ''Intimate Apparel'' and ''Fabulation or, the Re-Education of Undine'', hooks her audience with promises of a conventionally structured, purposefully plotted play, stocked with sympathetic characters and informative topical detail. She delivers on those promises. Yet a raw and genuine agony pulses within and finally bursts through this sturdy framework, giving ''Ruined'' an impact that lingers beyond its well-shaped, sentimental ending. . . . Ms. Nottage has endowed the frail-looking Sophie, as well as the formidable Mama, with a strength that transforms this tale of ruin into a clear-eyed celebration of endurance."<ref>Brantley, Ben.[http://theater2.nytimes.com/2009/02/11/theater/reviews/11bran.html?pagewanted=1 "Theatre Review: War’s Terrors, Through a Brothel Window",]''The New York Times'', February 11, 2009</ref>
==Awards and nominations== ;[[Pulitzer Prize]]<ref>[http://www.pulitzer.org/citation/2009-Drama "The Pulitzer Prizes| Drama"] pulitzer.org, October 25, 2011</ref>
*Pulitzer Prize for Drama - '''''Winner'''''
;[[Drama Desk Awards]]<ref>Gans, Andrew.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/129323-Ruined_and_Billy_Elliot_Win_Top_Honors_at_Drama_Desk_Awards "Ruined and Billy Elliot Win Top Honors at Drama Desk Awards"] playbill.com, May 17, 2009</ref>
*Outstanding Play – '''''Winner''''' *Outstanding Actress in a Play, [[Saidah Arrika Ekulona]] – (nomination) *Outstanding Featured Actress in a Play, [[Condola Rashād|Condola Rashad]] – (nomination) *Outstanding Director of a Play, [[Kate Whoriskey]] – (nomination) *[[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Music in a Play|Outstanding Music in a Play]], Dominic Kanza - '''''Winner'''''
;[[Outer Critics Circle Award]]<ref>Gans, Andrew.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/129094-Billy_Elliot_Carnage_Ruined_and_Avenger_Are_Outer_Critics_Circle_Award_Winners "Billy Elliot, Carnage, Ruined and Avenger Are Outer Critics Circle Award Winners"], May 11, 2009</ref>
*Outstanding New Off-Broadway Play – '''''Winner''''' *Outstanding Lighting Design (Play or Musical) – Peter Kaczorowski (nomination) *Outstanding Actress in a Play – Saidah Arrika Ekulona (nomination) *Outstanding Featured Actress in a Play – Condola Rashad (nomination)
;[[Drama League Award]]<ref>Gans, Andrew.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/129267-Billy_Carnage_Hair_Blithe_and_Rush_Win_Drama_League_Awards "Billy, Carnage, Hair, Blithe and Rush Win Drama League Awards"] playbill.com, May 15, 2009</ref>
*Distinguished Production of a Play (nomination) *Distinguished Performance Award, Saidah Arrika Ekulona (nomination)
;[[Lucille Lortel Award]]<ref>Gans, Andrew.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/128877-Ruined_Fela%21_Our_Town_and_Humor_Abuse_Among_Lucille_Lortel_Award_Winners Ruined, Fela!, Our Town and Humor Abuse Among Lucille Lortel Award Winners"], playbill.com, May 3, 2009</ref>
*Outstanding Play (Manhattan Theatre Club and Goodman Theatre, Producer; Lynn Nottage, Playwright) – '''''Winner''''' *Outstanding Director (nomination) *Outstanding Lead Actress – Saidah Arrika Ekulona '''''Winner'''''
;[[Obie Awards]]<ref>Jones, Kenneth.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/129344 "Groff, Nottage, Sondheim, Cromer, Pisoni, Korins Among 2009 OBIE Award Winners"] playbill.com, May 18, 2009</ref> *Best New American Play '''''Winner''''' *Performance :Quincy Tyler Bernstine '''''Winner''''' :Saidah Arrika Ekulona '''''Winner''''' :Russell Gebert Jones '''''Winner'''''
==In print== [[Theatre Communications Group]] has published the script. ''Ruined'' began stocking in stores November 1, 2009.

"Review, Ruined", ''Curtain Up'', February 5, 2009] * [http://www.charlierose.com/guest/view/6678 Charlie Rose interview] about production of ''Ruined'', July 14, 2009, 12 minute video

{{for|the ice hockey player|Kevyn Adams}}
'''Kevin Adams''' is an American theatrical [[lighting designer]]. He has earned three [[Tony Awards]] for lighting design.
==Biography== Adams grew up in Texas and attended the [[University of Texas]] where he received a B.F.A. in scenery design, then attended the [[California Institute for the Arts]] where he received a master's degree, also in scenic design. He toured with [[Rachel Rosenthal]], a performance artist, for 5 years, and also worked as a set designer at various theaters and in film in [[California]], before moving to New York.<ref>Barbour, David.[http://google.com/search?q=cache:Y9hMzhEPuW4J:livedesignonline.com/mag/lighting_unexpected_kevin_adams/+%22Kevin+Adams%22+lighting&cd=3&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us&lr=lang_en "The unexpected Kevin Adams"], livedesignonline.com, November 1, 1998</ref><ref name=texas>Staff.[http://www.finearts.utexas.edu/tad/about_us/spotlights/design_and_production/lighting/kevin_adams.cfm "Interview with Tony Award-winning designer Kevin Adams, UT alumnus"], finearts.utexas.edu, c. 2007, accessed May 20, 2009</ref>
In 2007 he received the [[Tony Award for Best Lighting Design]] of a [[Musical theatre|Musical]] for ''[[Spring Awakening (musical)|Spring Awakening]]''. In 2008 he received the Tony Award for Best Lighting Design of a Play and the [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Lighting Design]] for ''[[The 39 Steps (play)|The 39 Steps]]''. In 2010 he received his third Tony Award (for light design of a musical) for his work on "[[American Idiot (musical)|American Idiot]]". Other productions include ''[[Hedwig and the Angry Inch (musical)|Hedwig and the Angry Inch]]'', ''[[Passing Strange]]'', ''[[Next to Normal]]'', the 2009 revival of ''[[Hair (musical)|Hair]]'', ''[[Take Me Out (play)|Take Me Out]]'', [[Everyday Rapture]]", solo shows for [[Anna Deveare Smith]], [[Eve Ensler]], [[Eric Bogosian]] and [[John Leguizamo]], concerts for [[Audra McDonald]], [[Patti Lupone]], [[Sandra Bernhard]] and [[The Magnetic Fields]]. Adams has worked at many regional and off-Broadway theaters and operas, including: [[The Public Theater]], [[Roundabout Theatre]], [[Second Stage Theatre]], [[Encores!]], [[Williamstown Theatre Festival]], [[Lincoln Center]], [[Kennedy Center]], [[Playwrights Horizons]], [[P.S. 122]], [[Steppenwolf Theatre]], [[Donmar Warehouse]], [[New York City Opera]], [[Glimmerglass Opera]], and [[Houston Grand Opera]].
In 2009 he received two Tony nominations for lighting ''[[Hair (musical)|Hair]]'' and ''[[Next To Normal]]''. In 2010, he was nominated for his work on ''[[American Idiot (musical)|American Idiot]]''. 2002 he received an [[Obie Award]] for Sustained Excellence<ref>[http://www.villagevoice.com/obies/search Obie Awards listing] villagevoice.com, accessed May 20, 2009</ref> and in 1998 and 2007 he received [[Lucille Lortel Award]]s for Outstanding Lighting of an [[Off-Broadway]] production. He received the [[Henry Hewes Design Award]] in 2007 for lighting ''Spring Awakening'' and in 2010 for ''Hair''<ref>[http://www.lortel.org/lla_archive/index.cfm?search_by=people&first=Kevin&middle=&last=Adams Off-Broadway Database, listing awards] lortel.org, accessed May 20, 2009</ref> and in 2011 for ''American Idiot''.
His 1992 video about the 1991 [[gay bashing]] murder of Houstonian [[Paul Broussard]], ''[[Can't Take That Away From Me]]'', was internationally exhibited including the [[Margaret Mead Film Festival]], [[American Film Institute]] and [[British Film Institute]].<ref name=texas/>
His photography is included in the permanent collection of the [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.ibdb.com/person.asp?ID=25504 Kevin Adams] at the [http://www.ibdb.com/default.asp Broadway internet database] *[http://www.lortel.org/LLA_archive/index.cfm?search_by=people&keyword=name&first=Kevin&last=Adams&middle= Kevin Adams] at the [http://www.lortel.org/LLA_archive/index.cfm Off-Broadway internet database] *[http://www.ambermylar.com/ Official site] *[http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Broadway_Bullet_Interview_Tony_Nominee_Kevin_Adams_20070609 ''BroadwayWorld.com'' interview with Kevin Adams, June 9, 2007]
