revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = Harold Gould |image = HaroldGould.jpg |imagesize = |caption = Harold Gould in 2010 |birthname = Harold V. Goldstein |birth_date = {{Birth date|1923|12|10}} |birth_place = [[Schenectady, New York]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|2010|9|11|1923|12|10}} |death_place = [[Woodland Hills, California]] |occupation = Actor |yearsactive = 1961–2010 |spouse = Lea (Shampanier) Vernon (August 20, 1950 – September 11, 2010; his death; 3 children) }} '''Harold V. Goldstein, PhD''' (December 10, 1923 – September 11, 2010<ref name="latimesblogs.latimes.com">http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/afterword/2010/09/character-actor-harold-gould-dies-at-86.html</ref>), best known by his stage name '''Harold Gould''', was an American actor best known for playing Miles Webber on the 1985-1992 sitcom ''[[The Golden Girls]]'' and Martin Morgenstern in the 1970s sitcom ''[[Rhoda]]''. Gould acted in film and television for nearly 50 years, appearing in more than 300 television shows, 20 major motion pictures, and over 100 stage plays, and received [[Emmy Award]] nominations five times.<ref name="albany">[http://www.albany.edu/writers.inst/gould_harold.html Harold Gould], New York State Writers Institute. Retrieved on 2006-08-13.</ref> He is known for playing elegant, well-dressed men (as in ''[[The Sting]]''), and he regularly played Jewish characters and grandfather-type figures on television and film.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}}
==Early life== Gould was born to a [[Jewish]] family in [[Schenectady, New York]] to Louis and Lillian Goldstein. Louis was a postal worker, and Lillian was a homemaker who did part-time work for the state health department. Gould was raised in [[Colonie, New York]] and was [[valedictorian]] of his high school class. He enrolled at Albany Teachers College upon graduation (now known as [[University at Albany, The State University of New York|University at Albany, SUNY]]), and studied to become a social studies or English teacher.
After two years in college, Gould enlisted in the [[United States Army]], during [[World War II]], and saw combat in [[France]] in a [[chemical mortar battalion|mortar company]].<ref name="albany"/> He developed [[immersion foot|trenchfoot]], and was sent to England to recover. After convalescence, Gould served in a [[rail transport]] unit in France.<ref name="what">[http://www.what-a-character.com/cgi-bin/display.cgi?id=982796220 Harold Gould], What A Character!. Retrieved on 2006-08-13.</ref>
After the war, Gould returned to Albany Teachers College to study drama, and graduated with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in 1947.<ref name="filmbug">[http://www.filmbug.com/db/292690 Harold Gould @ Filmbug], Misja.com, retrieved on 2006-08-13.</ref> He performed in [[summer stock theatre]] on [[Cape Cod]], then decided to enroll at [[Cornell University]] to study drama and speech. Gould earned a master of arts degree in 1948 and a Ph.D. in theatre in 1953 from Cornell, and also met his future wife, Lea Vernon.
==Career== Upon graduation, Gould accepted a position at [[Randolph-Macon Woman's College]] in [[Lynchburg, Virginia|Lynchburg]], [[Virginia (U.S. state)|Virginia]], where he spent three years teaching and doing stage work.<ref name="what"/> He made his professional theatre debut in 1955 as [[Thomas Jefferson]] in ''The Common Glory'' in [[Williamsburg, Virginia|Williamsburg]].<ref name="yahoo">[http://movies.yahoo.com/movie/contributor/1800012754/bio Harold Gould biography], Yahoo! Movies. Retrieved on 2006-08-13.</ref>
In 1956, Gould was offered a professorship in the drama department at the [[University of California, Riverside]],<ref name="filmbug"/> which he accepted. He taught there until 1960, when he decided to try professional acting himself.<ref name="what"/> He had difficulty finding acting jobs at first, and had to take work as a security guard and as a part-time acting teacher at [[UCLA]].<ref name="albany"/>
Gould made his film debut in ''[[Two for the Seesaw]]'' but was not credited for his work; his first credited role was a small part in ''The Coach'' in 1962. He gradually found more work and got roles in ''[[The Yellow Canary]]'', a [[Rod Serling]] movie with [[Pat Boone]], [[Jack Klugman]], and [[Barbara Eden]]; ''[[The Satan Bug]]''; ''[[Inside Daisy Clover]]''; and ''[[Harper (film)|Harper]]'', starring [[Paul Newman]].
Gould worked steadily in television in the 1960s and early 1970s, including roles in ''[[Dennis the Menace (1959 TV series)|Dennis the Menace]]'', ''[[Dr. Kildare#Television|Dr. Kildare]]'', ''[[Hazel (TV series)|Hazel]]'', ''[[The Twilight Zone (1959 TV series)|The Twilight Zone]]'', ''[[The Donna Reed Show]]'', ''[[Get Smart]]'', ''[[Hogan's Heroes]]'', ''[[The F.B.I. (TV series)|The F.B.I.]]'', ''[[The Big Valley]]'', ''[[Cannon (TV series)|Cannon]]'' and ''[[Mission: Impossible]]''. Gould originated the role of [[Marlo Thomas]]'s father Lou in the 1965 pilot for ''[[That Girl]]'', but the series role went to Lew Parker. He appeared in ''[[The Long Hot Summer (TV series)|The Long, Hot Summer]]'' and ''[[He and She]]'', two short-lived television series. Gould also acted in a [[Television pilot|pilot]], later broadcast as a 1972 episode of ''[[Love, American Style]]'' titled "Love and the Happy Days" as Howard Cunningham, the frustrated father of a young man named [[Richie Cunningham]] (played by [[Ron Howard]]).<ref name="NYT" >Hal Erickson, [http://movies2.nytimes.com/gst/movies/filmography.html?p_id=27975&mod=bio Harold Gould biography]. Allmovie excerpt published in the [[New York Times]]. Retrieved on 2006-08-13.</ref>
When [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] turned that episode into a series called ''[[Happy Days]]'', Gould was tabbed to reprise the Howard Cunningham role. However when production was delayed, he went abroad to perform in a play. Midway through the play's run, after learning ''Happy Days'' was ready to begin shooting, he decided to honor his commitment to the stage production and passed on the part, which led to [[Tom Bosley]] being cast as the family patriarch. Gould would later state that a requirement to shave his beard was also a factor in his declining the role.<ref>McLellan, Dennis. [http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-me-harold-gould-20100914,0,1952380.story Harold Gould obituary], ''Los Angeles Times'', 14 September 2010 (retrieved 14 September 2010)</ref>
Gould had worked in television and film for almost fifteen years before his career really took off with his portrayal of Kid Twist in ''[[The Sting]]''. He appeared in the [[Woody Allen]] movie ''[[Love and Death]]'', as a villain in ''[[Silent Movie]]'' (directed by [[Mel Brooks]]), and made guest appearances on television shows such as ''[[Hawaii Five-O]]'', ''[[Petrocelli]]'', ''[[Soap (TV series)|Soap]]'', and ''[[The Love Boat]]''. On ''Soap'' Gould played the hospital roommate of the character Jody ([[Billy Crystal]]) who has suicidal feelings while deciding whether or not to undergo a sex change. Gould's character sometimes refers to Jody as a 'fagela', which is [[Yiddish]] for a gay man. [[File:Harold Gould Martin Morgenstern Mary Tyler Moore 1973.jpg|thumb|200px|Gould as Martin Morgenstern on ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' in 1973.]] In 1972, Gould was cast as Martin Morgenstern, the father of Mary's best friend Rhoda, in an episode of ''[[The Mary Tyler Moore Show]]''. He reprised the role the following year and was hired as a regular when ''[[Rhoda]]'' was made into a [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]] in 1974. After ''Rhoda'' ended, Gould appeared in short-lived series such as the 1977 series ''The Feather and Father Gang'', where he starred as Harry Danton, a smooth-talking ex-con man, with [[Stefanie Powers]] as Toni "Feather" Danton, his daughter and a hard-working, successful lawyer. It ran for 13 episodes.
He also appeared in the miniseries ''[[Washington: Behind Closed Doors]]''. In the 1980 NBC miniseries ''[[Moviola]]'', he portrayed [[Louis B. Mayer]] and gained an [[Emmy]] nomination. He appeared as [[Chad Lowe]]'s grandfather in ''[[Spencer (TV series)|Spencer]]'', and played a Jewish widower wooing the Christian [[Katharine Hepburn]] in ''[[Mrs. Delafield Wants to Marry]]''. Other roles included a married man having an affair with another member of his [[Yiddish|Yiddish-speaking]] club in an episode of the [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] series ''The Sunset Years'', and as the owner of a deli grooming two African-American men to inherit his business in ''[[Singer & Sons]]''.<ref name="yahoo"/> Gould received [[Emmy award|Emmy]] nominations for his roles in ''Rhoda'', ''Mrs. Delafield Wants to Marry'' and ''Moviola''.
Gould played Miles Webber, the steadfast boyfriend of [[Rose Nylund]] ([[Betty White]]) on the [[NBC]] series ''[[The Golden Girls]]'' (he also played a different boyfriend of Rose's named Arnie in the show's first season). He portrayed the father of a villain called The Prankster on ''[[Lois & Clark: The New Adventures of Superman]]'' and made guest appearances on television series such as ''[[Felicity (TV series)|Felicity]]'', ''[[The King of Queens]]'', ''[[Touched by an Angel]]'', and ''[[Judging Amy]]''. Gould's film roles in the 1990s and 2000s include appearances in ''[[Stuart Little (film)|Stuart Little]]'', ''[[Patch Adams (film)|Patch Adams]]'', ''[[Master of Disguise]]'', the [[2003 in film|2003]] remake of ''[[Freaky Friday (2003 film)|Freaky Friday]]'', ''[[Nobody's Perfect (2004 film)|Nobody's Perfect]]'', and ''[[Whisper of the Heart (film)|Whisper of the Heart]]''.
His stage credits include [[Broadway theatre]] plays such as [[Jules Feiffer]]'s ''Grown Ups'', [[Neil Simon]]'s ''[[Fools (play)|Fools]]'', Richard Baer's ''Mixed Emotions'', and [[Tom Stoppard]]'s ''Artist Descending a Staircase''. Gould won an [[Obie Award]] in 1969 for his work in ''The Increased Difficulty of Concentration'', written by [[Václav Havel]], and reprised the role for a 1988 PBS version of the play.<ref name="albany"/> Gould was an early and longtime (48 years) member of [[Theatre West]], the oldest membership theatre company in Los Angeles.<ref>http://theatrewest.org/company.html</ref> He played Mr. Green in [[Jeff Baron]]'s ''[[Visiting Mr. Green]]" at the Pasadena Playhouse.
==Personal life== Gould lived in [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]] with his wife, Lea (Shampanier) Vernon. He died from [[prostate cancer]] on September 11, 2010.<ref name="latimesblogs.latimes.com"/> He is survived by two sons, Joshua and Lowell, and a daughter, Deborah. After his death he was [[cremated]]<ref>http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=58583692</ref> and his ashes were given to his family. He and Lea were married for 60 years.
==Selected works== ===Films=== * ''[[The Lawyer (film)|The Lawyer]]'' (1969) * ''[[The Sting]]'' (1973) * ''[[The Front Page (1974 film)|The Front Page]]'' (1974) * ''[[Love and Death]]'' (1975) * ''[[Gus (1976 film)|Gus]]'' (1976) * ''[[The Big Bus]]'' (1976) * ''[[Silent Movie]]'' (1976) * ''[[The One and Only (1978 film)|The One and Only]]'' (1978) * ''[[11th Victim]]'' (1979 TV movie) * ''[[Seems Like Old Times (film)|Seems Like Old Times]]'' (1980) * ''[[King Crab]]'' (1980 TV movie) * ''[[Moviola: The Silent Lovers]]'' (1980 TV movie) * ''[[Moviola: The Scarlett O'Hara War]]'' (1980 TV movie) * ''[[Kenny Rogers as The Gambler]]'' (1980 TV movie) * ''[[The Dream Chasers]]'' (1982) * ''[[Mrs. Delafield Wants to Marry]]'' (1986 TV movie) * ''[[Playing for Keeps (1986 film)|Playing for Keeps]] '' (1986 movie) * ''[[Romero (film)|Romero]]'' (1989) * ''[[The Sunset Gang]]'' (1991 TV movie, episode "Yiddish") * ''[[For Hope]]'' (1996 TV movie) * ''[[The Love Bug]]'' (1997 TV movie) * ''[[Patch Adams (film)|Patch Adams]]'' (1998) * ''[[Beloved (film)|Beloved]]'' (1998) (uncredited) * ''[[My Giant]]'' (1998) * ''[[Brown's Requiem (film)|Brown's Requiem]]'' (1998) * ''[[Stuart Little (film)|Stuart Little]]'' (1999) * ''[[The Master of Disguise]]'' (2002) * ''[[Brother Bear]]'' (2003) (voice) * ''[[Freaky Friday (2003 film)|Freaky Friday]]'' (2003) * ''[[Nobody's Perfect (2004 film)|Nobody's Perfect]]'' (2004) * ''[[Whisper of the Heart (film)|Whisper of the Heart]]'' (2006) or ''Mimi wo sumaseba'' (original release 1995) (voice, English dub) {{div col end}}
===Television=== {{div col|cols=4}} * ''[[National Velvet (TV series)|National Velvet]]'' * ''[[The Eleventh Hour (1962 TV series)|The Eleventh Hour]]'' * ''[[The Donna Reed Show]]'' * ''[[Empire (1962 TV series)|Empire]]'' as Judge Will in "Stopover on the Way to the Moon" (1963) * ''[[Nip/Tuck]]'' * ''[[Judging Amy]]'' * ''[[Touched by an Angel]]'' * ''[[The King of Queens]]'' * ''[[Pacific Blue (TV series)|Pacific Blue]]'' * ''[[Felicity (TV series)|Felicity]]'' * ''[[The Outer Limits (1995 TV series)|The Outer Limits]]'' * ''[[Lois & Clark: The New Adventures of Superman]]'' * ''[[The Golden Palace]]''- Miles (Rose's boyfriend) * ''[[The Golden Girls]]'' - Miles (recurring as Rose's boyfriend) * ''[[The Rockford Files]]'' * ''[[The Ray Bradbury Theater]]'' * ''[[Dallas (1978 TV series)|Dallas]]'' * ''[[Empty Nest (TV series)|Empty Nest]]'' * ''[[Night Court]]'' * ''[[L.A. Law]]'' * ''[[Scarecrow and Mrs. King]]'' * ''[[St. Elsewhere]]'' * ''[[Insight (TV series)|Insight]]'' * ''[[Soap (TV series)|Soap]]'' * ''[[Police Story (TV series)|Police Story]]'' * ''[[Petrocelli]]'' * ''[[Hawaii Five-O]]'' * ''[[Cannon (TV series)|Cannon]]'' * ''[[Rhoda]]'' - recurring * ''[[Gunsmoke]]'' * ''[[The Streets of San Francisco]]'' * ''[[Ironside (TV series)|Ironside]]'' * ''[[The Mary Tyler Moore Show]]'' * ''[[The Partridge Family]]'' * ''[[The F.B.I. (TV series)|The F.B.I.]]'' * ''[[The Mod Squad]]'' * ''[[Hogan's Heroes]]'' * ''[[I Dream of Jeannie]]'' * ''[[Mission: Impossible]]'' * ''[[The Debbie Reynolds Show]]'' * ''[[The Big Valley]]'' * ''[[The Wild Wild West]]'' * ''[[The Flying Nun]]'' * ''[[The Fugitive (TV series)|The Fugitive]]'' * ''[[The Green Hornet#Television|The Green Hornet]]'' * ''[[Get Smart]]'' * ''[[That Girl]]'' - pilot only * ''[[The Virginian (TV series)|The Virginian]]'' * ''[[Hazel (TV series)|Hazel]]'' * ''[[The Jack Benny Show]]'' * ''[[Dr. Kildare#Television|Dr. Kildare]]'' * ''[[Mister Ed]]'' * ''[[Perry Mason (TV series)|Perry Mason]]'' * ''[[The Man from U.N.C.L.E.]]'' * ''[[The Twilight Zone (1959 TV series)|The Twilight Zone]]'' * ''[[The Alfred Hitchcock Hour]]'' * ''[[Dennis the Menace (1959 TV series)|Dennis the Menace]]'' * ''[[The Invaders]]'' * ''The Feather and Father Gang (1976-1977 TV Series) Co-starring Stefanie Powers {{div col end}}

'''Eugene V. "Gene" Frankel''' (December 23, 1919 – April 20, 2005) was an [[United States|American]] actor, theater director, and acting teacher especially notable in the founding of the off-Broadway scene. Frankel served in the Army during World War II in entertainment and as a member of an aerial crew.
==Life and career== Frankel's direction of the off-Broadway production of [[Jean Genet]]'s ''[[The Blacks (play)|The Blacks]]'' was regarded as a crucial production in promoting African-American theater during the civil-rights movement which opened in 1961 and ran for more than 1,400 performances at the St. Mark's Theatre.<ref>[http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/2008/12/clip_job_mailer_3.php ''Village Voice'' May 11, 1961, Vol. VI, No. 29]</ref> The cast included James Earl Jones, Roscoe Lee Browne, Louis Gossett, Cicely Tyson, Godfrey Cambridge, Maya Angelou and Charles Gordone.
He began his own career as an actor and was one of the earliest members of the [[Actors Studio]]. He moved behind the scenes and became a theater director on and off Broadway. His most notable Broadway production was [[Arthur Kopit]]'s ''[[Indians (play)|Indians]]'' starring [[Stacy Keach]], who won the 1970 [[Tony Award]] as Best Actor for his portrayal of [[Buffalo Bill]]. <ref>[http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/archives/2010/08/john_lahr_digs.php ''Village Voice'' October 16, 1969, Vol. XIV, No. 53]</ref> The production was also nominated for a [[Tony Award]] for best play of 1970.
His other Broadway productions included ''A Cry of Players'' (1968), [[Kurt Weill]]'s ''[[Lost in the Stars]]'' (1972) and [[Harry Chapin]]'s ''[[The Night That Made America Famous]]'' (1975). His off-Broadway productions included ''Brecht on Brecht'', (starring [[Viveca Lindfors]], [[Lotte Lenya]], [[Eli Wallach]] and [[Anne Jackson]]), and ''[[To Be Young, Gifted and Black]]'' starring [[Cicely Tyson]]. He directed an [[Arthur Miller]] play when Miller was married to [[Marilyn Monroe]].
==Gene Frankel Theatre== As well as directing over 200 shows and managing at least twelve theaters throughout his career, Frankel taught acting, writing and directing. His last stage was the ''Gene Frankel Theatre and Film Workshop'' at 24 Bond Street in Greenwich Village. Frankel said that the heart of successful acting was, ''Truth. I don't let my actors tell lies. The camera doesn't lie, the stage doesn't let you lie.'' {{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} He was a visiting professor in theater at various institutions of higher learning including [[Columbia University]], [[Boston College]], and [[New York University]].
On August 4, 1973, his [[Mercer Arts Center]], a complex of seven small theaters, which had been located on the first two floors of the residential Broadway Central Hotel, physically collapsed. Frankel, who had been conducting a rehearsal at the time, noticed the ceiling and walls beginning to buckle and heroically led the actors and several residents to safety; five people died in the collapse. <ref>NY Daily News, p. 1, Saturday, August 4<sup>th</sup>, 1973</ref> <ref>NY Post, p. 1, Saturday, August 4<sup>th</sup>, 1973</ref> <ref>NY Times, pp. 13–15, Saturday, August 4<sup>th</sup>, 1973</ref>
Only his last theater was a financial success, serving as home to artistic director Christopher Groenwald's New Mercury Players and as a satellite location for artistic director Marilyn Majeski's <ref>[http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/bostonglobe/obituary.aspx?pid=158662722 Marilyn Majeski obituary], Boston Globe, July 22, 2012</ref> Grove Street Playhouse.
===Gail Thacker=== In 2003 Gene Frankel made Gail Thacker<ref>[http://thevillager.com/villager_300/channelingicons.html "Channeling icon’s spirit while trying to pay the rent"]. Monica Uszerowicz, The Villager, Volume 78, Number 35, January 28<sup>th</sup> - February 3<sup>rd</sup>, 2009.</ref> Managing Director of The Gene Frankel Theatre and Film Workshop at the Bond Street location. Upon Gene Frankel's death his legacy passed into Thacker's trust.<ref>[http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9902E5D71731F931A15757C0A9639C8B63 "Gene Frankel, Acting Coach And Director, Is Dead at 85"]. Jesse McKinley, NY Times, April 22<sup>nd</sup>, 2005.</ref><ref>[http://www.genefrankeltheatre.com/aboutus.html Official website]. Gene Frankel Theatre.</ref>
===August Strindberg Repertory Theatre=== {{Main|August Strindberg Repertory Theatre}} The August Strindberg Repertory Theatre became the resident company at the Gene Frankel Theatre when it transferred its first production, a co-production with the Negro Ensemble Company of [[August Strindberg|Strindberg's]] ''Playing with Fire'', there in June 2012 after an initial run at the [[New School for Drama|New School]]'s theater. It has since produced a double bill (''Casper's Fat Tuesday'' and ''[[The Stronger]]'') and ''[[Easter (play)|Easter]]''. "Casper's Fat Tuesday" was a co-production with the Pink Pig Ballet.
==Family== Frankel had two children, Laura Frankel and Ethan Frankel, from his marriage which ended in divorce. He was survived by his daughter, Laura Frankel. His son, an aspiring actor, who studied at his father's school had struggled with marijuana use and psychiatric illness which led him to leap off the top of a 17-floor-building during 1995 in Manhattan during a psychosis from which he miraculously survived. After a lengthy coma and therapy to learn to walk again Ethan was placed in a group home in the Bronx where he was murdered by a fellow resident the following year. Frankel created a scholarship at his theater in his son's name.<ref name="Daily News">[http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/1997/04/04/1997-04-04_real-life_tragedy_for_acting.html Daily News]</ref>
==Awards and honors== Frankel was awarded the first [[Obie Award]] for directing, with his production of ''[[Volpone]]'' (1958) and then won two more also for directing. He also received the first Lola d'Annunzi and Vernon Rice awards for outstanding achievement in theater. ===[[Obie Award]]s=== * 1956–57 — Best Director — Ben Jonson's ''[[Volpone]]'' <ref>[http://www.villagevoice.com/obies/index/1957/ ''Village Voice'' Obies 1957]</ref> * 1959–60 — Best Director — Sophie Treadwell's ''[[Machinal]]'' <ref>[http://www.villagevoice.com/obies/index/1960/ ''Village Voice'' Obies 1960]</ref> * 1960–61 — Best Play — [[Jean Genet]]'s ''[[The Blacks (play)|The Blacks]]'' <ref>[http://www.villagevoice.com/obies/index/1961/ ''Village Voice'' Obies 1961]</ref>
===other=== * [[Drama Desk Award]] — Vernon Rice Award — Outstanding Achievement in Theatre * Lola D'Annunzio Award — Lifetime Achievement In Theatre
==References== ;Notes {{Reflist}}
===Obituaries=== * [http://www.nytimes.com/2005/04/22/theater/22frank.html ''New York Times'' April 22, 2005] * [http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117921711 ''Variety'' April 26, 2005] * [http://www.thevillager.com/villager_104/genefrankel85.html ''Villager'' April 27 - May 3, 2005, Vol. 74, No. 51]
==External links== * {{Official|http://www.genefrankeltheatre.com}} Gene Frankel Theatre ** [http://www.ibdb.com/person.asp?ID=14814 "Gene Frankel"] on the [[Internet Broadway Database]] * {{Official|http://www.strindberg.org}} August Strindberg Repertory Theatre ** {{Facebook|StrindbergRep|August Strindberg Repertory Theatre}} ** [http://strindbergrep.blogspot.com/ August Strindberg Repertory Theatre blog]
{{Persondata | NAME = Frankel, Gene | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = April 20, 2005 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Frankel, Gene}} [[Category:1920s births]] [[Category:2005 deaths]] [[Category:American military personnel of World War II]] [[Category:American stage actors]] [[Category:American theatre directors]] [[Category:Deaths from myocardial infarction]] [[Category:Obie Award recipients]]

{{Redirect|Obie}} {{Infobox award | name = Obie Awards | image = | imagesize = | caption = | description = Excellence in [[Off-Broadway]] [[theatre]] | presenter = [[The Village Voice]] | country = [[United States]] [[New York City]] | year = 1956 | website = [http://www.villagevoice.com/obies/ www.villagevoice.com/obies] }}
The '''Obie Awards''' or '''Off-Broadway Theater Awards''' are annual awards given by ''[[The Village Voice]]'' newspaper to theatre artists and groups in New York City. As the [[Tony Awards]] cover [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] productions, the Obies cover [[Off-Broadway]] and [[Off-Off-Broadway]] productions.
==Background== The Obie Awards were initiated by Edwin (Ed) Fancher, publisher of ''The Village Voice,'' who handled the financing and business side of the project. They were first given in 1956 under the direction of theater critic Jerry Tallmer. Initially, only Off-Broadway productions were eligible; in 1964, Off-Off-Broadway productions were made eligible.
==Award structure== With the exception of the Lifetime Achievement and Best New American Play awards, there are no fixed categories and the winning actors and actresses are in a single category titled "Performance". There are no announced nominations.<ref>Healy, Patrick. [http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/05/18/ruined-wins-obie-awards/ "'Ruined' Wins Obie Awards"] ''The New York Times'', May 18, 2009</ref><ref>Gans, Andrew. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/116870.html "Camp, Harris, Merkerson, Marvel and White to Present at Obies; Passing Strange to Perform"], playbill.com, April 17, 2008</ref> Awards in the past have included [[acting|performance]], [[Theatre director|direction]], best production, [[design]], special citations, and sustained achievement. Not every category is awarded every year. ''The Village Voice'' also awards annual Obie grants to selected companies; in 2011, these grants were $2,000 each to [[Metropolitan Playhouse]] and Wakka Wakka.<ref name=play1>Gans, Andrew.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/150893-Chad-Deity-Ethan-Hawke-Laurie-Metcalf-Thomas-Sadoski-Charlayne-Woodard-Win-Obie-Awards " 'Chad Deity', Ethan Hawke, Laurie Metcalf, Thomas Sadoski, Charlayne Woodard Win Obie Awards"] playbill.com, May 16, 2011</ref> There is also a Ross Wetzsteon Grant, named after its former theater editor, in the amount of $2,000 (in 2009; in 2011 the grant was $1,000), for a theatre that nurtures innovative new plays.<ref>Cox, Gordon.[http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118003900.html?categoryId=15&cs=1 Off Broadway event] ''Variety'', May 18, 2009</ref>
The first awards in 1955-1956 for plays and musicals were given to ''Absalom'' (Lionel Abel) as Best New Play, ''[[Uncle Vanya]]'', Best All-Around Production and ''[[The Threepenny Opera]]'' as Best Musical.<ref>[http://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0153525.html "1955–1956 Obie Awards"] infoplease.com, accessed May 21, 2013</ref>
Other awards for Off-Broadway theatre are the [[Lucille Lortel Awards]], the [[Drama Desk Awards]], the [[Drama League Award]], and the [[Outer Critics Circle Awards]].
==Ceremony== The ceremony for the 2010–11 season was held on May 16, 2011 at Webster Hall (New York City), hosted by [[S. Epatha Merkerson]] and [[David Hyde Pierce]].<ref name=play1/> The ceremony for 2011–12 was held on May 21, 2012 at Webster Hall.<ref>Gans, Andrew. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/166170-4000-Miles-Gabriel-Ebert-Mary-Louise-Wilson-Linda-Lavin-Santino-Fontana-and-More-Are-Obie-Winners "'4000 Miles', Gabriel Ebert, Mary Louise Wilson, Linda Lavin, Santino Fontana and More Are Obie Winners"] playbill.com, May 21, 2012</ref> The ceremony for the 2012-2013 season was held at Webster Hall on May 20, 2013, with hosts [[Jessica Hecht]] and Jeremy Shamos.<ref>Gans, Andrew. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/178152-Detroit-Grimly-Handsome-Eisa-Davis-John-Rando-Shuler-Hensley-and-More-Are-Obie-Winners "'Detroit', 'Grimly Handsome', Eisa Davis, John Rando, Shuler Hensley and More Are Obie Winners"] playbill.com, May 20, 2013</ref>
===Categories and winners=== *'''Lifetime Achievement Award''' ** 2011-2012 - [[Lois Smith]] and [[Frances Sternhagen]] ** 2010-2011 - Repertorio Espanol and its co-founder and artistic director, René Buch ** 2009-2010 - no award ** 2008-2009 - [[Earle Hyman]] ** 2007-2008 - [[Adrienne Kennedy]] ** 2006-2007 - Alvin Epstein
*'''[[Obie Award for Distinguished Performance by an Actress]]'''
*''' Obie Award for Distinguished Performance by an Actor'''
*''' Obie Award for Distinguished Performance by an Ensemble'''
== Lists of winners == * [http://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0153524.html Winners from Infoplease.com] * [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/108214.html$ OBIE winners, 2006–2007], playbill.com * [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/117880.html OBIE winners, 2007–2008], playbill.com * [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/129344-Groff-Nottage-Sondheim-Cromer-Pisoni-Korins-Among-2009-OBIE-Award-Winners OBIE winners, 2008–2009], playbill.com * [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/139593-Circle-Mirror-Transformation-Aliens-Metcalf-and-More-Win-OBIE-Awards OBIE winners, 2009–2010], playbill.com * [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/150893-Chad-Deity-Ethan-Hawke-Laurie-Metcalf-Thomas-Sadoski-Charlayne-Woodard-Win-Obie-Awards OBIE winners, 2010–2011], playbill.com * [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/178152-Detroit-Grimly-Handsome-Eisa-Davis-John-Rando-Shuler-Hensley-and-More-Are-Obie-Winners OBIE winners, 2011-2012], playbill.com

'''Melissa James Gibson''' is a Canadian-born [[playwright]] based in New York.
==Life== The child of former [[British Columbia Liberal Party|BC Liberal]] [[Member of the Legislative Assembly|MLA]] [[Gordon Gibson]] and his journalist wife Valerie, Gibson grew up in North Vancouver.<ref>[http://www.theprovince.com/entertainment/This+perfect+return+Vancouver+born+playwright/4066326/story.html ]{{dead link|date=May 2013}}</ref> She graduated from [[Columbia University]] and from the [[Yale School of Drama]] with an M.F.A. in Playwriting. She is working on commissions for the [[La Jolla Playhouse]] and The Adirondack Theatre Festival. She has received fellowships from the Jerome Foundation and the [[MacDowell Colony]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newdramatists.org/melissa_james_gibson.htm# |title=Alumni Playwrights |publisher=New Dramatists |date= |accessdate=2013-05-22}}</ref> The New York Times theatre critic Charles Isherwood wrote that with her play This, Gibson “graduates into the theatrical big leagues with this beautifully conceived, confidently executed and wholly accessible work.” <ref>[http://www.theprovince.com/entertainment/This+perfect+return+Vancouver+born+playwright/4066326/story.html#ixzz1AfOz4iQW ]{{dead link|date=May 2013}}</ref>
==Awards== * 2002 [[Obie Award|Obie]] for playwriting, Kesselring Prize, The Best Plays of 2001–02 for ''[sic] ''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/obies/search |title=New York Search Obies Theater Awards |publisher=Villagevoice.com |date=2012-10-17 |accessdate=2013-05-22}}</ref> * 2002 [[Whiting Writers' Award]] * 2011 [http://broadwayworld.com/article/BWW-TV-2011-Steinberg-Playwrights-Awards-Honors-Melissa-James-Gibson-and-Lisa-DAmour-Inside-the-Event-20111115 Steinberg Playwright Award]
==Works== * [http://books.google.com/books?id=NAjEKscAyCIC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Melissa+James+Gibson&cd=1#v=onepage&q=&f=false ''[sic]''] Steppenwolf Theatre Company commission * ''Suitcase, or Those That Resemble Flies From A Distance'' (NEA/ TCG Theatre Residency Program, 2004 production at Soho Rep) * ''Brooklyn Bridge'', music by Barbara Brousal (The Children's Theater Company/New Dramatists Playground program commission) * ''Given Fish'' (Steppenwolf Theatre Company commission, grants from the New York State Council on the Arts and the Greenwall Foundation) * ''Six Fugues'' * ''God's Paws'' * ''Nuda Veritas'' * ''Current Nobody'', Woolly Mammoth Theatre Company, DC, 2007 * ''This'', Playwrights Horizons, 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theatermania.com/off-broadway/news/12-2009/melissa-james-gibsons-this-extends-at-playwrights_23380.html |title=Melissa James Gibson's This Extends at Playwrights Horizons Through January 3 – Theater News – Dec 7, 2009 |publisher=Theatermania.com |date=2009-12-07 |accessdate=2013-05-22}}</ref> Canadian Premiere: [[Vancouver Playhouse Theatre Company|Vancouver Playhouse]], January 2011, directed by [[Amiel Gladstone]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.doollee.com/PlaywrightsG/gibson-melissa-james.html "Melissa James Gibson", ''doollee'] *[http://playwrightsfoundation.blogspot.com/2008/11/interview-with-melissa-james-gibson.html "Interview with Melissa James Gibson", ''Playwrights Foundation'', November 11, 2008] *[http://www.observer.com/node/48769 "Melissa James Gibson: Lady of the Flies", ''The New York Observer'', John Heilpern, February 8, 2004]

{{US-playwright-stub}}

'''W. David Hancock''' is an [[United States|American]] [[playwright]]. ==Life== Hancock graduated from the [[University of Iowa]] Playwriting workshop, with an MFA.http://www.pwcenter.org/lab.php?uid=769&s=1 Playwriting Center website His play ''The Convention of Cartography'' was performed in 1994 by The Foundry Theatre at a gallery in Chelsea.http://www.thefoundrytheatre.org/html/history.html The Foundry Theatre website{{cite news|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2008-01-01/theater/under-the-radar-tries-its-hand-at-site-specific-work/2|title=Under the Radar Tries its Hand at Site-Specific Work| author=Alexis Soloski|date=1 January 2008|work=The Village Voice}} His play ''The Race of the Ark Tattoo'' played at PS122 and the Cherry Lane Theater, and toured regionally. ==Awards== *1998 [[Whiting Writers' Award]] *2000 CalArts/Alpert Award for theatre[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb4309/is_200009/ai_n15023188/ Newspaper article re 2000 CalArts] *Bush Artist Fellowship *1999 Obie Award[http://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0777962.html Newspaper article re 1999 Obies] *1995 Obie Award[http://www.villagevoice.com/obies/search Village Voice article re 1995 Obies] ==Works== *''Convention of Cartography'' CSPS, Midwest Center for Developing Artists in [[Cedar Rapids, Iowa]] *''The Race of the Ark Tattoo'', CSPS, Midwest Center for Developing Artists in Cedar Rapids, Iowa *''With a Dead March'' at On the Boards New City Theater, Seattle October 2005{{cite news|url=http://www.seattleweekly.com/2005-08-03/diversions/best-mom-and-pop-theater/|title=Best Mom-and-Pop Theater|author=Steve Wiecking|work=Seattle Weekly|date=3 August 2005}} *''The Puzzle Locker'' University of Iowa Theatres Mainstage 2006[http://www.news-releases.uiowa.edu/2006/february/022006puzzle_locker.html University of Iowa news release] ==Reviews==
''The Race of the Ark Tattoo'' is an exploration of the nebulous territory between memories and dreams. It takes place not in a theater but in a flea market (installed in a gallery on the side of P.S.122).[http://www.curtainup.com/raceark.html CurtainUp.com]
==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.doollee.com/PlaywrightsH/hancock-w-david.html "W David Hancock", ''doollee''] *[http://playswithothers.blogspot.com/2009/11/convention-of-cartography-by-w-david.html "The Convention of Cartography - by W. David Hancock ", ''Daily Plays'', 8 November 2009] *{{cite news|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2003-05-20/theater/the-plays-what-they-wrote/1|title=The Plays What They Wrote|author=Alexis Soloski|date=20 May 2003|work=The Village Voice}} {{Persondata | NAME = Hancock, W. David | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hancock, W. David}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of Iowa alumni]] [[Category:Obie Award recipients]] {{US-playwright-stub}}

:''For the senior RAF officer, see [[Richard Jordan (RAF officer)]].'' {{Infobox person | name = Richard Jordan | image = | imagesize = 200px | birth_name = Robert Anson Jordan, Jr.[http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0CE5D71730F932A3575AC0A965958260 Richard Jordan dies at 56]. | birth_date = {{Birth date|1937|07|19}} | birth_place = [[New York City, New York|New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], {{nowrap|United States}} | death_place = [[Los Angeles, California]], {{nowrap|United States}} | death_cause =[[Brain tumor]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1993|08|30|1937|07|19}} | resting_place=[[Cremation]] | occupation = Stage, film, and television actor | yearsactive = 1961–1993 | spouse = [[Kathleen Widdoes]]
(1964-1972)
one daughter, Nina | domesticpartner = [[Marcia Cross]] (1985-1993)
[[Blair Brown]]
(1976-1985)
1 son, Robert Christopher Hand {{IMDb name|0430151}}}} '''Richard Jordan''' (born '''Robert Anson Jordan, Jr.''', July 19, 1937 – August 30, 1993) was an [[United States|American]] [[stage (theatre)|stage]], [[Big screen|screen]], and [[television]] [[actor]]. A long-time member of the [[New York Shakespeare Festival]], he performed in many [[Off Broadway]] and [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] plays. His films include ''[[Logan's Run (1976 film)|Logan's Run]]'', ''[[Les Misérables (1978 film)|Les Misérables]]'', ''[[Raise the Titanic (film)|Raise the Titanic]]'', ''[[The Friends of Eddie Coyle]]'', ''[[The Yakuza]]'', ''[[The Bunker]]'', ''[[Dune (film)|Dune]]'', ''[[The Secret of My Success (1987 film)|The Secret of My Success]]'', ''[[The Hunt for Red October (film)|The Hunt for Red October]]'', ''[[Posse (1993 film)|Posse]]'' and ''[[Gettysburg (1993 film)|Gettysburg]]''. ==Early life== Jordan was born in [[New York City]], to Robert Anson Jordan, Sr., from [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], and Constance Hand-Jordan, from New York. His maternal grandfather was [[Learned Hand]], judge of the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit]], and one of the most respected jurists in the United States. In 1942, when Jordan was five years old, his parents divorced. His mother married [[Newbold Morris]], president of the [[New York City Council]]. The marriage was performed by Mayor [[Fiorello LaGuardia]] at [[Gracie Mansion]], the first marriage to be solemnized there."Morris Marries Mrs. C. H. Jordan", ''[[The New York Times]]'', August 2, 1942 ==Career== Following his graduation from [[Harvard University]] in 1958, Jordan began his acting career in earnest. In 1961, he appeared on Broadway with [[Art Carney]] and [[Elizabeth Ashley]] in ''[[Take Her, She's Mine]]''. He also began working in television productions, appearing in episodes of ''[[The Defenders (1961 TV series)|The Defenders]]'', ''[[Naked City]]'', ''[[Empire (1962 TV series)|Empire]]'', and ''[[The Wide Country]]''. He performed with [[Joseph Papp]]'s [[Public Theater]] in productions of [[Shakespeare]]'s plays, such as ''[[The Tempest]]'', ''[[The Merchant of Venice]],'' and ''[[As You Like It]]''. In 1966, Jordan returned to Broadway, appearing in ''[[Generation]]'' with [[Henry Fonda]]. Beginning in 1970, Jordan turned from television to feature film work. He co-starred in [[Lawman (film)|''Lawman'']] (1971) and ''[[Valdez Is Coming]]'' (1971) with [[Burt Lancaster]], and appeared opposite [[Robert Mitchum]] twice, in ''[[The Friends of Eddie Coyle]]'' (1973), as the informant-Coyle's handler, a pragmatic U.S. Treasury agent; and in ''[[The Yakuza]]'' (1975) as the bodyguard of Mitchum's friend, George Tanner. He played a host of villains and mixed good guy-villains in films such as Hawk in [[Rooster Cogburn (film)|''Rooster Cogburn'']] (1975), ''[[Logan's Run (1976 film)|Logan's Run]]'' (1976), and ''Interiors'' (1978). There was also the occasional "good guy", as in ''Old Boyfriends'' (1979), in which he played the father of his own daughter, Nina. Jordan also continued on the stage, joining [[Ralph Waite]] in the [[L.A. Actor's Theatre]]. He also wrote, directed and performed in plays such as ''Venus of Menschen Falls'' (1978)."An Actor Who Dares to Turn Off TV, ''Los Angeles Times'', February 7, 1978 In 1976, he starred as Joseph Armagh, an Irish [[immigrant]] who fights his way to power and wealth but loses his soul along the way, in the television miniseries ''[[Captains and the Kings]]''. Jordan earned a [[Golden Globe award]], and an [[Emmy]] nomination for the production. In the 1980s, Jordan performed in films including ''Raise the Titanic'' (1980), ''Flash of Green'' (1984), ''[[Dune (film)|Dune]]'' (1984), ''[[The Mean Season]]'' (1985) and ''The Secret of My Success'' (1987). He also co-starred in an acclaimed television production of ''The Bunker'' (1981), playing [[Albert Speer]] to [[Anthony Hopkins]]'s [[Hitler]]. In ten episodes of the popular television series ''[[The Equalizer]]'' (1987–1988), he helped fill in while the star, [[Edward Woodward]], recovered from a heart attack. Meanwhile, Jordan continued on the stage as well, winning an [[Obie]] award for his appearance in New York in the [[Czechs|Czech]] playwright [[Václav Havel]]'s ''[[A Private View]]'' (1983) and an [[L.A. Drama Critic's Award]] for directing another Havel play, ''[[Largo Desolato]]'' (1987). In 1990, Jordan directed a production of ''Macbeth'' in New York City. He played national security advisor Jeffrey Pelt in ''The Hunt for Red October''. He starred in a television production of ''Three Hotels'' (1991) and the 1991 "Deadline" episode of ''[[Tales from the Crypt]]''. In ''[[Posse (1993 film)|Posse]]'' (1993), Jordan portrays Bates, a racist sheriff with his own plans for land on which the [[Negro]] town of Freemanville stands. His health began to fail and he was diagnosed with a [[brain tumor]]. He was filming ''[[The Fugitive (1993 film)|The Fugitive]]'' in April 1993 when his terminal illness forced him to withdraw.''Variety'', April 23, 1993 He died on August 30, 1993, cared for by his daughter Nina and his companion, [[Marcia Cross]]."Her Midlife Miracle, ''Good Housekeeping'', March 2007 Jordan's last film to be released was ''[[Gettysburg (1993 film)|Gettysburg]]'' (1993), which was filmed during the summer of 1992."'[[Killer Angels]]' Filming Begins Today",''Gettysburg Times'', July 20, 1992 He portrayed Confederate Brig. Gen. [[Lewis Addison Armistead|Lewis "Lo" Armistead]], who was one of the leaders in the doomed Pickett's Charge against his friend from before the war, Union Gen. [[Winfield Scott Hancock]]. Producer-Director [[Ronald Maxwell]] dedicated the film to Jordan and to author [[Michael Shaara]], whose novel ''[[The Killer Angels]]'' was adapted for the film. ==Personal life== Jordan's daughter, Nina Jordan, was born in 1964, during his 1964–72 marriage to actress [[Kathleen Widdoes]]. His son, Robert Christopher Hand Jordan, was born in 1982, during his nine-year relationship with actress [[Blair Brown]]. At the time of his death, Jordan was in a five-year relationship with actress [[Marcia Cross]].{{cite news | title = Richard Jordan, Actor, Director, Producer and Writer, 56, Is Dead | work = New York Times | date = 1993-09-01 | accessdate = 2008-04-03 |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1993/09/01/obituaries/richard-jordan-actor-director-producer-and-writer-56-is-dead.html }} A memorial in Jordan's honor was held at the [[Mark Taper Forum]] in Los Angeles on October 8, 1993, the day ''[[Gettysburg (1993 film)|Gettysburg]]'' was released.''Los Angeles Times'', October 8, 1993 ==Filmography== * ''[[Lawman (1971 film)|Lawman]]'' (1971) * ''[[Valdez Is Coming]]'' (1971) * ''[[The Trial of the Catonsville Nine]]'' (1972) * ''[[Chato's Land]]'' (1972) * ''[[Kamouraska (film)|Kamouraska]]'' (1973) * ''[[The Friends of Eddie Coyle]]'' (1973) * ''[[The Yakuza]]'' (1974) * ''[[Rooster Cogburn (film)|Rooster Cogburn]]'' (1975) * ''[[Logan's Run (1976 film)|Logan's Run]]'' (1976) * ''[[Captains and the Kings]]'' (1976) (TV miniseries) * ''[[Alibis]]'' (1977) * ''[[Interiors]]'' (1978) * ''[[Les Misérables (1978 film)|Les Misérables]]'' (1978) * ''[[A Nightingale Sang in Berkeley Square (film)|A Nightingale Sang in Berkeley Square]]'' (1979) * ''[[Old Boyfriends]]'' (1979) * ''[[Raise the Titanic (film)|Raise the Titanic]]'' (1980) * ''[[The Bunker (1981 film)|The Bunker]]'' (1981) * ''[[A Flash of Green]]'' (1984) * ''[[Dune (film)|Dune]]'' (1984) * ''[[The Mean Season]]'' (1985) * ''[[The Men's Club]]'' (1986) * ''[[Solarbabies]]'' (1986) * ''[[The Murder of Mary Phagan]]'' (1987) * ''[[The Secret of My Success (1987 film)|The Secret of My Success]]'' (1987) * ''[[Romero (film)|Romero]]'' (1989) * ''[[The Hunt for Red October (film)|The Hunt for Red October]]'' (1990) * ''[[Delusion (film)|Delusion]]'' (1991) * ''[[Timebomb (1991 film)|Timebomb]]'' (1991) * ''[[Heaven Is a Playground]]'' (1991) * ''[[Shout (film)|Shout]]'' (1991) * ''[[Primary Motive]]'' (1992) * ''[[Posse (1993 film)|Posse]]'' (1993) * ''[[Gettysburg (1993 film)|Gettysburg]]'' (1993) ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Portal|Biography|New York|California|Theatre|Film|Television}} * {{Find a Grave|7503620}} * {{IMDb name|0430151}} {{GoldenGlobeBestActorTVDrama 1969-1989}} {{Authority control|VIAF=10043222}} {{Persondata |NAME =Jordan, Richard |ALTERNATIVE NAMES =Robert Christian Anson Jordan, Jr. |SHORT DESCRIPTION =Actor |DATE OF BIRTH =July 19, 1937 |PLACE OF BIRTH =[[New York City, New York]], |DATE OF DEATH =August 30, 1993 |PLACE OF DEATH =[[Los Angeles, California]], }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jordan, Richard}} [[Category:1937 births]] [[Category:1993 deaths]] [[Category:People from New York City]] [[Category:People from Los Angeles, California]] [[Category:American film actors]] [[Category:American stage actors]] [[Category:American television actors]] [[Category:Cancer deaths in California]] [[Category:Deaths from brain '''Mina Bern''' (May 5, 1911 – January 10, 2010)<ref name=NYTObit>{{cite news|title=Mina Bern, Versatile Yiddish Actress, Dies at 98|first=Joseph|last=Berger|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 12, 2010|accessdate=January 13, 2010|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/13/theater/13bern.html}}</ref><ref name=NYTKvell>{{cite news|title=Kvelling Over a Matriarch of the Yiddish Theater|first=Corey|last=Kilgannon|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 12, 2010|accessdate=January 13, 2010|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/13/nyregion/13yiddish.html}}</ref> was a Polish-born [[United States|American]] actress. She was a star of the [[Yiddish theater]].<ref name="Queen of mamaloshen">[http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1144291.html Queen of mamaloshen]</ref>
==Biography== Mina (Bernholtz) Bern was born in [[Bielsk Podlaski]]. Her theatrical debut was in Bialystock under the director Yehuda Greenhoyz.<ref name=forward>http://yiddish.forward.com/oldarchive/090806/ Yiddish Forverts Sept. 8 2006</ref> In 1930, through her relative [[Moishe Broderzon]], she shortened her name and auditioned successfully to join the Ararat Yiddish cabaret theater in [[Lodz]].<ref name="Queen of mamaloshen"/> and then played at the Warsaw ''Scala'' and later, the Kaminska theaters and the local folk theater. With Dina Halperin and Sam Bronetski she worked in the collective ''Our Theater'', and later with Zygmunt Turkov.<ref name=zalmen>Zalmen Zylbercweig, ''Leksikon fun Yidishn teater'', Book three column 2296</ref> A few years later, she established a small cabaret theater in [[Białystok]].
Bern fled to Russia with her daughter after the [[Nazi invasion of Poland]]; there she played with the "Bialistocker yidishn miniatur-teatr" (miniature revi-teater)<ref name=forward/> of [[Shimon Dzigan]] and [[Israel Shumacher]]. In 1944 she was sent to a camp in Uganda where she did children's theater for Poles stationed there. Through Jewish family connections she went to Kenya in 1945 and from there to [[Israel]] where she worked with Jenny Lavitz in the revue ''Rozhinkes mit mandlen,'' favorably reviewed and subsequently staged at the Hebrew ''Li-La-Lo'' revue theater.<ref name=zalmen />
In 1949, after an incident in which she was found guilty of sending a thug to beat up theater critic [[Haim Gamzu]], who had written a bad review of her performance, she emigrated to the [[United States]].<ref name="Queen of mamaloshen"/> She married the actor and producer Ben Bonus. She was a member of the Hebrew Actors' Union and recorded songs in [[Hebrew]].
==Awards== Bern received an [[Obie award]] in 1999.
==Filmography== *''[[Brooklyn Babylon]]'' (2001) .... Nanna *Flawless (1999) .... Mrs. Spivak *Celebrity (1998) .... Elderly Homeowner *The First Seven Years (1998) (TV) .... Landlady *I'm Not Rappaport (1996) * Everything Relative (1996) .... Grandma Kessler * Little Odessa (1994) .... Grandma Tsilya * It Could Happen to You (1994) .... Muriel's Neighbour * Pressure Drop (1994) .... Ida Potashner * Avalon (1990) .... Alice Krichinsky * [[Crossing Delancey]] (1988) .... Would-be Victim * Tenement (1985) (as Mina Bern Bonas) .... Ruth
==See also== *[[Music of Israel]] *[[Shoshana Damari]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{IMDb name|id=0075957}}

{{Infobox person | image = | caption = | birth_name = Philip Charles Anglim | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1953|2|11}} | birth_place = [[San Francisco]], [[California]], [[United States]] | years_active = 1973–present | occupation = Actor | partner = | alma mater = [[Yale University]] <small>([[Bachelor's degree|B.A.]] - 1973)</small> }}
'''Philip Charles Anglim''' (born February 11, 1953) is an [[United States|American]] actor best known for his performance as [[Joseph Merrick]] in the stage and television versions of ''[[The Elephant Man (play)|The Elephant Man]]'', a role for which he received a Best Actor nomination in the 1979 [[Tony Awards]]. Other notable roles include ''[[Macbeth]]'' on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] and Dane O'Neill, the ill-fated love child who grew up to follow in his unknown father's footsteps on the path to the priesthood, in the television mini-series ''[[The Thorn Birds]]''. He also had a recurring guest role as the Bajoran priest [[Vedek Bareil]] on ''[[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine]]''.
==Biography== Anglim was born in [[San Francisco, California]]. His father, a [[Catholic]] of [[Irish people|Irish]] descent, worked as a patent attorney, while his mother was of [[French people|French]] and [[Jewish]] descent and was an art dealer.<ref>[http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20075279,00.html "Philip Anglim Had to Go Through Contortions to Import and Star in 'the Elephant Man'"]. ''People''. December 10, 1979. Retrieved May 6, 2011.</ref> He originally aspired to become a [[veterinarian]], but after he was asked to appear in a play by one of his teachers, he switched to acting. Anglim graduated with a bachelor's degree in [[English literature]] from [[Yale University]] in 1973. Subsequently, Anglim spent a year in [[Connecticut]] at the Southbury Playhouse.
His feature film debut was in ''The All-American Boy'' (1973), and his first television appearance was in the PBS ''The Adams Chronicles'' (1976). In 1979, while still an unknown, Anglim optioned the London play ''The Elephant Man'', and debuted off-Broadway at St. Peter's Church. It later moved to The Booth Theater on Broadway in 1979, and earned several awards. He performed [[Macbeth]] on Broadway in 1981 (in which he was replaced by [[Kelsey Grammer]]) and again on TV in 1982. In 1982, Anglim appeared in the NBC television version of ''The Elephant Man'', and earned Best Actor nominations for the performance.
Anglim also maintains a cattle farm in [[Tennessee]], and in 1992, founded The Lewis County Children's Fund, to help children in the area.
==Awards== All of the following were for his performance in ''The Elephant Man'': * 1979 Outstanding Actor in a Play, Drama Desk Award * 1979 nomination for Best Actor, Tony Awards * 1979 Theatre World Award * 1978-1979 OBIE Award Performance * 1982 nomination, Emmy Award * 1982 nomination, Golden Globe [http://www.littlereview.com/getcritical/trektalk/anglim.htm] * Dramalogue award, ''Lonely Planet''
==Works== ===Theater=== * ''What the Butler Saw'', 1975, Cincinnati * ''The Contrast'', 1975, Cincinnati * ''Snow White'', 1976, New York * ''[[The Elephant Man (play)|The Elephant Man]]'' (1977) * ''Macbeth'', 1981, New York
===Film/television=== * ''[[The Elephant Man (TV film)|The Elephant Man]]'' (1982) as John Merrick * ''Haunted Summer'' as Lord Byron * ''The Man Inside'' as Rolf Gruel * ''The Thorn Birds'' as Dane O'Neill * ''Dallas'' reunion ''War of the Ewings'' * ''Millennium'' * ''Macbeth'' (title role) * ''[[Testament (film)|Testament]]''
===Star Trek appearances=== * "[[In the Hands of the Prophets (DS9 episode)|In the Hands of the Prophets]]" * "[[The Circle (DS9 episode)|The Circle]]" * "[[The Siege (DS9 episode)|The Siege]]" * "[[Shadowplay (DS9 episode)|Shadowplay]]" * "[[The Collaborator (DS9 episode)|The Collaborator]]" * "[[Fascination (DS9 episode)|Fascination]]" * "[[Life Support (DS9 episode)|Life Support]]" * "[[Resurrection (DS9 episode)|Resurrection]]"
{{More footnotes|date=February 2010}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{iMDb name|0001911}} * [http://www.littlereview.com/getcritical/trektalk/anglim.htm "Philip Anglim, Holy Man] * [http://www.angelfire.com/mo/gutterduck/credits.html List of credits] * [http://www.hollywood.com/celebs/detail/id/188984 Hollywood.com biography] {{memoryalpha}} * [http://www.angelfire.com/mo/gutterduck Philip Anglim fansite]
{{DramaDesk PlayOutstandingActor 1975-2000}}

'''Paul Shyre''' (8 March 1926–19 November 1989) was an [[United States|American]] director and [[playwright]] who won a [[Tony Award|Tony]] and an [[Emmy Award|Emmy]].<ref name="Haymer">Haymer, Johnny (21 November 1989) ''The Washington Post'' page B-7</ref> He is noted for the plays ''Hizzoner'', ''[[Will Rogers' USA]]'' and ''The President Is Dead''.<ref>Mikulan, Steven (27 January 2006) "Let's Put On a Banned Show" ''LA Weekly'' page 68</ref>
Shyre graduated from the [[University of Florida]] and the [[American Academy of Dramatic Arts]]. He was a professor of theater arts at [[Cornell University]].<ref>Flint, Peter B. (20 November 1989) [http://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/20/obituaries/paul-shyre-63-director-actor-and-o-casey-adapter-is-dead.html?pagewanted=1 "Paul Shyre, 63, Director, Actor And O'Casey Adapter, Is Dead"] ''The New York Times'' page D-11</ref>
Shyre adapted to the stage, directed and co-produced the Sean O'Casey novels, ''Pictures in the Hallway'', ''I Knock at the Door'' and ''Drums Under the Windows''. He also wrote and directed ''A Whitman Portrait'' and ''An Unpleasant Evening With H.L. Mencken''.<ref name="Haymer"/>
==Awards== *1957 Drama Desk Award for ''Pictures in the Hallway''<ref>Staff (5 November 2007) [http://broadwayworld.com/article/New_Globe_Revives_Paul_Shyres_Plays_in_Rep_Nov24Dec23_20071105 "New Globe Revives Paul Shyre's Plays in Rep Nov.24-Dec.23 2007/11/05"] Broadway World News Desk</ref> *1957 [[Obie Award]], special citation for bringing O'Casey to Off-Broadway; for his adaptations of ''I Knock at the Door'', ''Pictures in the Hallway'', and ''USA''<ref>[http://www.villagevoice.com/obies/index/1957 "New York Obies Theater Awards - 1957"]</ref> *1957 [[Special Tony Award]] *1987 shared an Emmy Award with Robert H. Rines for the television and later Broadway play ''Hizzoner'' about Mayor [[Fiorello La Guardia]].
==Notes== {{Reflist}}

{{lead too short|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox person |name=Juliet Rylance |image= |caption= |birth_date=26 July 1979 |birth_place=[[Hammersmith, London]] }} '''Juliet Rylance''' (born 26 July 1979) is an [[Obie Award]]-winning [[England|English]] [[actress]].<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/name/nm1628115/ Internet Movie Database Juliet Van Kampen]</ref>
==Personal life== Rylance was born '''Juliet van Kampen''' in [[London]], to Claire van Kampen, a composer, and Chris van Kampen, an architect.<ref>{{cite web|author=Matthew Gurewitsch |url=http://www.beyondcriticism.com/2010/01/christian-camargo-juliet-rylance |title=A Bridge of Two: In the Wings with Christian Camargo and Juliet Rylance, Matthew Gurewitsch, Jan. 12, 2010 |publisher=Beyondcriticism.com |date=2010-01-12 |accessdate=2010-05-26}}</ref> Her stepfather is the British actor and director [[Mark Rylance]]. She graduated from the [[Royal Academy of Dramatic Art]] in 2002, with a B.A Honors in Acting.
In 2008, she married the American actor [[Christian Camargo]] at [[New York City Hall]]. She had met Camargo over a decade earlier when he worked with her stepfather at [[Shakespeare's Globe Theatre]].<ref name="nytimes1">[http://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/10/theater/10couple.html A Threesome: Husband, Wife, Shakespeare]; Matthew Gurewitsch, New York Times, January 5, 2010</ref>
==Career== Rylance's first major role upon leaving Rada was Medea In Neil LaBute's "[[Bash: Latterday Plays]]" at the Union Theatre in London. Rylance then went on to play Perdita in "[[The Winter's Tale]]" and Cressida in "[[Troilus and Cressida]]" at Shakespeare's Globe Theatre. Rylance then portrayed the British writer Mary Sidney ''I am Shakespeare'' written by her step-father Mark Rylance and directed by Matthew Warchus at the [[Chichester Festival Theatre]] and its UK tour. That same year, Rylance along with two of her contemporaries, [[David Sturzaker]] and director [[Tamara Harvey]] started their own production company, Theater of Memory. Rylance subsequently starred in the Theater of Memory's productions of ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' and ''[[Bash: Latter-Day Plays]]'', portraying [[Juliet Capulet|Juliet]] and Medea respectively.<ref name="nytimes1"/><ref>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/drama/3662480/Chilling-glimpses-of-nastiness.html Chilling Glimpses of Nastiness]; Charles Spencer, Telegraph.co.uk, January 12, 2007</ref>
In 2009, Rylance played [[Desdemona]] at the Theater for a New Audience in New York City, opposite [[John Douglas Thompson]]'s ''[[Othello]]'' for which she was nominated for a [[Lucille Lortel Award]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Lucille Lortel Awards, Lucille Lortel Foundation, Off-Broadway database |url=http://www.lortel.org/llf_awards/index.cfm?page=previous2009 |title=Lucille Lortel Awards 2009 |publisher=Lortel.org |date= |accessdate=2010-05-26}}</ref> Rylance next appeared in the [[Sam Mendes]] directed 2009-2010 Bridge Project, a joint venture between the [[Brooklyn Academy of Music]] in [[Brooklyn|Brooklyn, New York ]] and [[The Old Vic]] in London. Rylance appeared as [[Rosalind (As You Like It)|Rosalind]] and [[Miranda (Shakespeare)|Miranda]], respectively, with her husband appearing across from her as Orlando and [[Ariel (Shakespeare)|Ariel]].<ref name="nytimes1"/> Rylance was awarded a 2010 [[Obie Award]] for her performance as Rosalind.<ref>[http://www.villagevoice.com/2010-05-18/theater/the-2009-ndash-2010-off-broadway-season-winners/ 2009-2010 Off-Broaway Season Winners]; The Village Voice, May 18, 2010</ref>
In 2012, Rylance appeared in the horror film [[Sinister (film)|Sinister]] as the wife of lead actor [[Ethan Hawke]].<ref>http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1922777/</ref>
She produced a modern retelling of [[Anton Chekhov]]'s [[The Seagull]] written and directed by Christian Camargo together with [[Barbara Romer]],<ref>http://www.imdb.com/name/nm5002282/</ref> the founder of the New Globe Theater. The film stars Katie Holmes, William Hurt, Allison Janney, Cherry Jones, Russell Means, Michael Nyqvist, Jean Reno, Mark Rylance, and Ben Whishaw.<ref>http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118052482/?refCatId=13</ref><ref>http://www.imdb.com/title/tt2359381/</ref> and is scheduled to release in 2013.
==Selected stage work== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Play !! Role !! Notes |- |" The Winter's Tale" || [[Perdita]] || Shakespeare's Globe Theatre, UK. |- |" Troilus and Cressida" || [[Cressida]] || Shakespeare's Globe Theatre, UK. |- | ''[[Bash: Latter-Day Plays]]'' || Medea || The Trafalgar Studios, West End, London. |- |''I am Shakespeare''||[[Mary Sidney]]|| Chichester Festival Theatre and UK Tour. |- | ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' ||[[Juliet]] ||Middle Temple Hall, London. |- |''[[Othello]]''||[[Desdemona]]||Nominated - [[Lucille Lortel Award]], Best Featured Actress |- |''The Bridge Project: [[As You Like It]]''||[[Rosalind (As You Like It)|Rosalind]]||[[Obie Award]] |- |''The Bridge Project: [[The Tempest]]''||[[Miranda (Shakespeare)|Miranda]]|| |- |" Three Sister's" || [[Irina]] || Classic Stage Company |- |" The Cherry Orchard" || [[Varya]] || Classic Stage Company |- | " Ivanov" || [[Sasha]] || Classic Stage Company |}
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Korean name|[[Lee (Korean name)|Lee]]}} {{for|people with similar names|Lee Young-jin (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> |image = |imagesize = 150px | | name = Young Jean Lee | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1974|5|30|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Daegu]], [[South Korea]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = | nationality = | period = Contemporary | genre = Playwright, director | subject = | movement = Experimental, Avant-garde | influences = | influenced = | signature = | website = http://www.youngjeanlee.org }} {{Infobox Korean name |hangul = 이영진 |hanja = ! |mr = Yi Yǒngjin |rr = Yi Yeongjin }} '''Young Jean Lee''' (born 1974) is a [[Brooklyn]]-based playwright and director working in [[experimental theater]]. She is the artistic director of Young Jean Lee's Theater Company, a not-for-profit theater company dedicated to producing her work. Lee was called "one of the best experimental playwrights in America" by David Cote in ''Time Out New York''.<ref>[http://newyork.timeout.com/articles/theater/70670/the-shipment David Cote, “The Shipment,” ''Time Out New York'', January 2009]</ref>
==Background== Lee was born in South Korea in 1974 and moved to the United States when she was two years old. She grew up in [[Pullman, Washington]] and attended college at [[UC Berkeley]], where she majored in English. Immediately after college, Lee entered UC Berkeley’s English PhD program, where she studied Shakespeare for six years. In 2002, she moved to New York to become a playwright. She received an MFA from [[Mac Wellman|Mac Wellman's]] playwriting program at [[Brooklyn College]].<ref>[http://topics.nytimes.com/topics/reference/timestopics/people/l/young_jean_lee/index.html Editors, "Times Topics - Young Jean Lee," ''The New York Times'']</ref>
==Works== Lee's plays have premiered in [[New York City]] at [[Soho Repertory Theater]] (''Lear'',<ref>[http://newyork.timeout.com/articles/theater/82066/lear-at-soho-rep-theater-review David Cote, “ LEAR: Father disfigure,” ''Time Out New York'', January 2010.]</ref> ''The Appeal''<ref>David Cote, “The Appeal,” ''Time Out New York'', April 22–29, 2004.</ref>), [[The Kitchen]] (''The Shipment''<ref>Charles Isherwood, “Off-Center Refractions of African-American Worlds,” ''The New York Times'', January 2009.[http://theater2.nytimes.com/2009/01/13/theater/reviews/13ship.html]</ref>), [[The Public Theater]] (''Church''), [[P.S. 122]] (''Church'',<ref>Jason Zinoman, “Confronting Questions of Faith With a Few New Responses,” ''The New York Times'', May 2007.[http://theater2.nytimes.com/2007/05/09/theater/reviews/09chur.html]</ref> ''Pullman, WA''<ref>David Cote, “Pullman, WA,” ''Time Out New York'', March 2005</ref>), [[HERE Arts Center]] (''Songs of the Dragons Flying to Heaven''<ref>Anita Gates, “Laugh Now. You May Not When These Women Rule the World,” ''The New York Times'', September 2006.[http://theater.nytimes.com/2006/09/27/theater/reviews/27drag.html]</ref>), and the [[Ontological-Hysteric Theater]] (''Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals''). Her work has toured venues in Paris, Vienna, Hannover, Berlin, Zurich, Brussels, Budapest, Sydney, Bergen, Oslo, Trondheim, Rotterdam, Salamanca, Toulouse, Chicago, Chapel Hill, Portland, Seattle, Philadelphia, Columbus, Pittsburgh, Boston, Williamstown, and Minneapolis. Lee is currently under commission from [[Lincoln Center Theater]], [[Playwrights Horizons]], and the [[Oregon Shakespeare Festival]].
==Affiliations== Outside her own company, Lee has worked with Radiohole and the [[National Theater of the United States of America]]. She is a member of New Dramatists and 13P, and has been awarded residencies from [[Yaddo]], the [[MacDowell Colony]], the [[Ucross Foundation]], and [[Hedgebrook]].
==Publications== Lee's plays have been published in ''New Downtown Now'',<ref>New Downtown Now, edited by [[Mac Wellman]] and Young Jean Lee, University of Minnesota Press, June 2006</ref> an anthology edited with [[Mac Wellman]], ''Three Plays by Young Jean Lee'',<ref>Three Plays by Young Jean Lee (''Groundwork of the Metaphysic of Morals'', ''The Appeal'', ''Pullman, WA''), Samuel French, Spring 2006.</ref> ''[[American Theatre (magazine)|American Theatre]]'' magazine,<ref>Songs of the Dragons Flying to Heaven, American Theatre, September 2008.</ref> ''Songs of the Dragons Flying to Heaven and Other Plays'',<ref>Songs of the Dragons Flying to Heaven and Other Plays, Theatre Communications Group, April 2009.</ref> and ''The Shipment and Lear''.<ref>The Shipment and Lear, Theatre Communications Group, April 2010.</ref>
==Awards== Lee was a finalist for the 2010 [[Susan Smith Blackburn Prize]] for The Shipment,<ref>"2010 Susan Smith Blackburn Prize Finalist Announced," Susan Smith Blackburn prize website, retrieved April 2, 2010. [http://www.blackburnprize.org/finalists%202010.htm]</ref> and a recipient of the 2009 Brooklyn College Young Alumni Award, the ZKB Patronage Prize 2007 of the [[Zürcher Theater Spektakel]],<ref>[http://theaterspektakel.ch/index.php?id=109&L=1 ZKB Prize Zürcher Theater Spektakel ]</ref> the 2007 Emerging Playwright [[OBIE Award]], and a 2010 Prize in Literature from the [[American Academy of Arts and Letters]].<ref>"AAAL Announces 2010 Literature Award Winners," American Academy of Arts and Letters Website, retrieved April 2, 2010.[http://www.artsandletters.org/press_releases/2010literature.php]</ref> She is a 2011 [[Guggenheim Fellow]].<ref>http://www.gf.org/fellows/17049-young-jean-lee</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.youngjeanlee.org Young Jean Lee's Theater Company Official Website] * [http://youngjeanlee.org/press Young Jean Lee's Theater Company's Press and Publications Archive]

{{Infobox person | image = Elzbieta Czyzewska.jpg | imagesize = 170px | caption = | birthname = Elżbieta Justyna Czyżewska | birth_date = {{Birth date|1938|5|14|mf=y}} | death_date = {{dda|2010|06|17|1938|5|14|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Warsaw, Poland]] | death_place = [[New York City, New York]], U.S. | yearsactive = 1958–2010 | occupation = Actress |spouse=[[Jerzy Skolimowski]] (1959-1965; divorced)
[[David Halberstam]] (1965-1977; divorced) }} '''Elżbieta Justyna Czyżewska''' (May 14, 1938Some sources such as [http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=53822394 Find a Grave] and [http://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/18/arts/18czyz.html ''The New York Times''] cite April 14, 1938 – June 17, 2010) was a [[Poland|Polish]] actress active in both Poland and the United States. ==Early life== Czyżewska was born in [[Warsaw]] in 1938. She attended the State Academy of Theatre in Warsaw and was advised by the Dean that in order to play leading roles in Romantic repertory she should undergo plastic surgery: to reduce the size of her breasts. Her answer, after she consulted her colleagues in the anti-establishment Student Satirical Theatre, was "No way".[http://www.polishculture-nyc.org/elzbieta_czyzewska.htm/ Obituary (in Polish)] Her first marriage was to the film director [[Jerzy Skolimowski]]. {{Citation needed|date=June 2010}} In 1965, she married the ''New York Times'' Warsaw correspondent, [[David Halberstam]]. She left Poland for the United States with him, but they divorced in 1977. ==Career in Poland== At the peak of her film and theater career, and in trouble with the communist regime on account of her marriage to Halberstam - she was cast by the Polish director [[Andrzej Wajda]] in his film, ''Everything for Sale''. The young directors of the Polish new wave in cinema recognized their peer in breaking the conventions of superficial romantic comedy. In ''A Bride for the Australian'' (1963), ''Where is the General'' (1963) and ''Giuseppe in Warsaw'' (1964), Czyżewska created a character who was almost the reverse of the [[Cinderella]] versus [[Prince Charming]] formula, as it was her charm and wit that turned her suitors into ''her equals''. {{Citation needed|date=June 2010}} Not a "method" actor, she would never disappear into a character, nor would she, on the other hand, allow her striking persona to wholly define her succession of screen and theatre parts. [[Wojciech Has]] directed her performance in ''[[The Saragossa Manuscript (film)|The Saragossa Manuscript]]'' (1964). {{Citation needed|date=June 2010}} Besides the theater role that won her the major Golden Mask Award, Czyżewska had her most significant stage success in the Teatr Dramatyczny's 1965 production of [[Arthur Miller]]'s ''[[After the Fall (play)|After the Fall]]''. By now internationally recognized (from [[Moscow]] to [[San Salvador]]) as one of Poland's top young actors, {{Citation needed|date=June 2010}} she expanded her artistic range in two film dramas: ''Unloved'' (1965) and Wajda's ''Everything for Sale'' (1968). The dark mood of both these movies marked the country's disillusionment after a brief period of cultural "thaw". ''Unloved'', set shortly before the outbreak of [[World War II]], tells the story of a young Jewish woman's love affair whose ending coincides with the ominous atmosphere of the period, including its anti-Semitism. {{Citation needed|date=June 2010}} She became an outcast and exile due to her marriage to Halberstam, who was expelled from Poland for his sharp criticisms of the regime at the time. Czyżewska's career was disrupted, and when she returned in 1968 at Wajda's invitation to play in his film, ''[[Everything for Sale]]'', production was complicated by the March outbreak of student protests and the start of that year's anti-Semitic expulsions. Ironically, Czyżewska herself was expelled, and partly because she promptly accepted a role in exiled director [[Aleksander Ford]]'s adaptation of [[Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn]]'s ''The First Circle'', she was unable to work in Poland until 1980 with the rise of Poland's [[Solidarność]] (Solidarity) movement, led by [[Lech Wałęsa]]. {{Citation needed|date=June 2010}} ==Career in the United States== The 1987 [[Hollywood]] film ''[[Anna (1987 film)|Anna]]'' is loosely based on Czyżewska's life. In the film, an exiled European movie star played by [[Sally Kirkland]], struggles to find work in New York City following her divorce from a well-connected intellectual, presumably based on David Halberstam. Kirkland was nominated for an [[Academy Award]] in the Best Actress category for this role. {{Citation needed|date=June 2010}} Czyżewska continued doing theater work in the U.S., winning an Obie Award in 1990 for her role in ''Crowbar'' by Mac Wellman. Her American premieres also include other Wellman plays as well as [[Janusz Glowacki]]'s ''Hunting Cockroaches''. She performed in Ibsen's ''[[When We Dead Awaken]]'' at the American Repertory Theater, and in several productions at [[Yale Repertory Theater]]. She also played in ''Big Potato'' (by [[Arthur Laurents]]) at the [[Doris Duke]] Theater. Her American films include ''[[Music Box (film)|Music Box]]'', ''[[Running on Empty (1988 film)|Running on Empty]]'', Eduardo Machado's ''Exiles In New York'' and ''Putney Swope''. Her television appearances include the American Playhouse drama ''Misplaced'' on [[PBS]]. Her most recent theater roles were in [[Martha Clarke]]'s ''Vienna Lusthaus'', [[Hedda Gabler]] at the New Theatre Workshop in 2004, and 'Darkling' in 2006. In June 2007, she returned to Poland for a performance of ''Darkling'' in [[Gniezno]] at the Aleksander Fredro Teatr. In May 2005, Czyżewska was honored with the Cultural Award of Merit by the Consul General of the New York Polish Consulate. This is the highest award for a Polish American to receive. The ceremony began the first American retrospective of her work at the first New York Polish Film Festival, directed by Hanna Hartowicz. {{Citation needed|date=June 2010}} Her final leading role was in the film June Weddings, adapted from a play written and directed by Barbara Hammond, that brought her great critical praise on the film festival circuit. Her role of a Russian émigré in New York was called "superbly acted" and "a grown-up feast". "The delightful Elzbieta Czyzewska plays a Russian woman so slyly, seductively Old World and languorous she gives "v" its own beat when she says "love." Baltimore's City Paper (Oct 23, 2008). The film also starred Tom Noonan. ==Death== She died on June 17, 2010 in New York at the age of 72 from [[esophageal cancer]].[http://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/18/arts/18czyz.html?ref=obituaries ''New York Times'' obituary] John Guare wrote Erased/Elzbieta a tribute play to Elzbieta Czyzewska which premiered at Atlantic Theater in NY in 2011. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|0194533}} * [http://www.elzbietaczyzewska.com Official website] * [http://filmpolski.pl/fp/index.php/111341 Polish film database] * [http://www.rp.pl/artykul/495642_Elzbieta_Czyzewska_nie_zyje.html Elżbieta Czyżewska biodata] {{Authority control|VIAF=102178473}} {{Persondata |NAME= Czyżewska, Elżbieta |ALTERNATIVE NAMES= |SHORT DESCRIPTION=Actress |DATE OF BIRTH= May 14, 1938 |PLACE OF BIRTH= [[Warsaw, Poland]] |DATE OF DEATH= June 17, 2010 |PLACE OF DEATH= [[New York City]], New York, U.S. }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Czyzewska, Elzbieta}} [[Category:1938 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:Obie Award recipients]] [[Category:Actors from Warsaw]] [[Category:Polish emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Polish film actresses]] [[Category:Polish stage actresses]] [[Category:Cancer deaths in New York]] [[Category:Deaths from esophageal cancer]] {{Link GA|pl}}

'''Christopher Shinn''' is an [[United States of America|American]] [[playwright]]. He was born in [[Hartford, Connecticut]] in 1975 and lives in New York. His plays have been produced around the world.
==Life== His play ''Now or Later'' premiered at the [[Royal Court Theatre]] in London from 3 September 2008 to 1 November 2008. In 2009, his adaptation of ''[[Hedda Gabler]]'' premiered on Broadway at the Roundabout ([[American Airlines Theatre]]).
Shinn's plays have been premiered by the [[Royal Court Theatre]], [[Lincoln Center Theater]], [[Manhattan Theatre Club]], [[Playwrights Horizons]], the [[Vineyard Theatre]], [[South Coast Repertory]], and Soho Theatre, and later seen regionally in the United States and around the world. He has also written short plays for [[Naked Angels (theater company)|Naked Angels]], the 24 Hour Plays, and the [[New York International Fringe Festival]].
Shinn's plays are published in collections from [[Theatre Communications Group]] and [[A & C Black]], and in acting editions from [[Dramatists Play Service]] and [[Playscripts, Inc.]]
Shinn teaches playwriting at [[The New School for Drama]].<ref>(source: http://christophershinn.com)</ref>
He also participated in the [[Bush Theatre]]'s 2011 project ''Sixty Six'' where he wrote a piece based upon a chapter of the [[King James Bible]]<ref>http://www.bushtheatre.co.uk/biography/writers/</ref>
==Plays== *''Four'' *''Other People'' *''What Didn't Happen'' *''The Coming World'' *''Where Do We Live'' *''Dying City'' *''On the Mountain'' *''Now or Later'' *''Picked'' *''Teddy Ferrara''
==Awards== Shinn is the winner of an [[Obie Award|OBIE]] in Playwriting (2005) and a [[Guggenheim Fellowship]] in Playwriting (2005), was a [[Pulitzer Prize]] finalist (2008), was shortlisted for the [[Evening Standard Theatre Award]] for Best Play (2008), and has also been nominated for an [[Olivier Award]] for Most Promising Playwright (2003), a [[TMA Award]] for Best New Play (2006), a [[Lucille Lortel Award]] for Outstanding Play (2007), and a [[South Bank Show]] Award for Theatre (2008). He has received grants from the [[National Endowment for the Arts|NEA]]/[[Theatre Communications Group|TCG]] Residency Program and the Peter S. Reed Foundation, and he is a recipient of the [[Robert Chesley Award]] for Lesbian and Gay Playwriting.
==External links== * {{official|http://www.christophershinn.com/}} * [http://www.newschool.edu/drama The New School for Drama]
==References== {{Reflist}}

'''Harry Kondoleon''' was a [[gay]] [[United States|American]] [[playwright]] and [[novelist]].
He was born on February 26, 1955; and died of [[AIDS]] in [[New York City]] on March 16, 1994, aged 39.<ref>[http://www.nytimes.com/1994/04/07/arts/kondoleon-memorial.html?src=pm ''New York Times'', 07 April 1994] Retrieved 18 May, 2012</ref>
He graduated from [[Hamilton College (New York)|Hamilton College]] and the [[Yale]] School of Drama. He was awarded the [[Fulbright Program|Fulbright]], [[National Endowment for the Arts]], [[Rockefeller Foundation|Rockefeller]] and [[Guggenheim Fellowship|Guggenheim]] fellowships.
==Works== ===Plays=== *The Brides - 1980 *The Côte d'Azur Triangle - 1980 *Rococo - 1981 *Self-Torture and Strenuous Exercise - 1982 *Andrea Rescued - 1982 *Clara Toil - 1982 *The Fairy Garden - 1982 *Christmas on Mars - 1983 *Slacks and Tops - 1983 *Linda Her - 1984 *The Vampires - 1984 *Anteroom - 1985 *Play Yourself - 1988 *The Poet's Corner - 1988 *Zero Positive - 1988 *Love Diatribe - 1990 *The Houseguests *Saved or Destroyed - 1994
===Novels=== *The Whore of Tiampuan - 1991 *Diary of a Lost Boy - 1994
===Poetry=== *Rudy on Ruby and Nadine (Wedge pamphlet) *The death of understanding: Love poems - 1987
==Awards== *1982-1983 [[Obie Award]] for "most promising young playwright" (Shared with [[Tina Howe]] (for "distinguished playwriting"), and [[David Mamet]] (for [[Edmond (play)|Edmond]])) *1984-1985 [[Obie Award]] to Elizabeth Wilson for her role in Kondoleon's "Anteroom" *1992-1993 [[Obie Award]] for "The Houseguests" *2000-2001 [[Obie Award]] to [[Craig Lucas]] for directing "Saved or Destroyed"
==References== {{reflist}} *[http://www.doollee.com/PlaywrightsK/kondoleon-harry.html Playwright's Page on Dooleee.com] *[http://www.playwrightshorizons.org/ab_awards.htm Playwright's Horizons Awards Page] *[http://www.donshewey.com/theater_articles/harry_kondoleon.htm Article about a posthumous festival of Kondoleon's works in 2000] *[http://www.aegis.com/news/ads/1994/AD940487.html Obituary]
==External links== *[http://www.donshewey.com/theater_articles/harry_kondoleon_vvoice.html Article about "The Fairy Garden" and Kondoleon's work] *[http://www.villagevoice.com/theater/0047,mcnulty,20040,11.html Village Voice Review of "Saved or Destroyed"] *[http://www.rtjournal.org/vol_2/no_1/gross.html Article on Kondoleon's ''The Houseguests'', camp, and the philosophy of Kierkegaard]
